texts.en:
P. Nguyễn Thị (20211040014) is a 41-year-old female living in the town of huyện Yên Phong - tỉnh Bắc Ninh.  She is married and has 2 school-aged children. P. owns & operates a livestock business, raising pigs for sale. She has been engaged in this business for over 20 years and earns approximately 1.700.000 VND a month.


In 2008, P. joined SEDA to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and her ability to engage in business activities.  P. has successfully repaid a previous loan of 4.256.000 VND from SEDA. This previous loan was used to purchase breeding livestock. She is now requesting a new loan of 5.152.000 VND which will be used to purchase livestock feed & other supplies. This will be the 3rd loan taken out by P. from SEDA. She plans to use the additional revenue generated to improve the general living conditions of her family.


About SEDA:

The mission of SEDA (Center of Small Enterprise Development Assistance) is to provide microfinance services to the low income and disadvantaged people in rural areas of Hanoi and the Northern provinces of Vietnam.


*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in Vietnamese while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.


P. Nguyễn Thị (20211040014) là 41 tuổi nữ.  Cô ấy sống ở thành phố huyện Yên Phong - tỉnh Bắc Ninh.  Cô ấy đã lập gia đình và có 2 trẻ ở độ tuổi đi học.  Để kiếm sống, P. Sở hữu và thực hiện hoạt động kinh doanh.  Công việc kinh doanh hoạt động tại lĩnh vực nông nghiệp.  Mục đích chính của việc kinh doanh là chăn nuôi gia súc.  Trong khi không phải chỉ có các phương thức tạo nên thu nhập, mà nguồn thu nhập chính của công việc kinh doanh chủ yếu từ chăn nuôi heo để bán.  P. thực hiện công việc kinh doanh này trong hơn 20 năm.  Từ các hoạt động này, P. kiếm được khoảng 1.700.000 VND một tháng.


Vào 2008, P. đã tham gia SEDA để có thể tiếp cận với các dịch vụ tài chính giúp cải thiện  sinh hoạt và khả năng tham gia vào các hoạt động kinh doanh của cô ấy/ anh ấy.  P. đề nghị khoản vay lần đầu tiên từ SEDA.  Khoản vay trước đây được sử dụng mua con giống.  Cô ấy hiện đang đề nghị một khoản vay mới là 5.152.000 VND.  Khoản vay hiện tại sẽ được sử dụng để mua thức ăn gia súc & các loại cung cấp khác.  Khoản vay sẽ là 3rd khoản vay của người vay từ SEDA.  P. dự định sẽ sử dụng nguồn thu nhập bổ sung từ công việc kinh doanh  cải thiện điều kiện sống chung của gia đình người vay.


Về SEDA:

Nhiệm vụ của SEDA (Trung Tâm hỗ Trợ Phát Triển các Doanh Nghiệp Nhỏ) là cung cấp các dịch vụ tài chính vi mô cho những người có thu nhập thấp và kém may mắn trong các vùng nông thôn tại Hà Nội và các tỉnh phía Bắc Việt Nam

*Lưu ý: Để phát huy tối đa hiệu quả & giảm chi phí, khoản vay này đã được thông báo bằng biểu mẫu để có thể được Kiva tự động biên dịch. .  Do việc biên dịch thủ công các danh mục rất tốn kém, nên Kiva đã tạo biểu mẫu này cho phần Field Partner (Trường Đối Tác) cho phép họ tiếp tục thông báo các khoản vay bằng  Vietnamese trong khi cung cấp thông tin có chất lượng & chính xác cho người cho vay Kiva.  .

loans.name: Rowena

texts.en:
Rowena B. is from the village of Dalipuga, Iligan City. She is 48 years old. Rowena is married and has 1 school-aged child. Rowena owns & operates a sari-sari (variety) shop where she sells food & daily use products. She has been engaged in her business for over 8 years and earns approximately 8,000 PHP a month.

In 2009, Rowena joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and her ability to engage in business activities. She has successfully repaid a previous loan of 8,000 PHP from HSPFI. This previous loan was used to to purchase additional products to sell. Rowena is requesting a new loan of 11,000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional inventory & provide working capital. This will be the 3rd loan taken out by Rowena from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated to improve and expand her business. 

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is one of the accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.name: Saginbubu

texts.en:
Saginbubu M. is a 53-year-old widow who is engaged in breeding cattle. She has seven children who help her carry out this activity, which has become an important source of support for the family. Saginbubu has wide experience in animal breeding because she worked as a dairymaid and a stock keeper for a long time. She began her business using her starting capital of 20,000 Kyrgyz Soms to purchase two cows. She milks cows and sells milk to the local dairy factory.  Also, Saginbubu and her children cultivate potatoes on their own plot of land. They fertilize the land to get a rich harvest of high-quality products.
   
Saginbubu is a very responsible and persistent person and works hard in order to improve the family's living conditions. Saginbubu plans to use the loan of 50,000 Kyrgyz Soms to expand her business by purchasing cattle. With the revenues from the loan, Saginbubu plans to purchase a small field engine for tillage. 

Bai-Tushum and Partners uses Kiva funding to target the especially vulnerable population. Bai-Tushum and Partners is one of the leading Microfinance Institutions in Kyrgyzstan. As a reliable financial partner, Bai-Tushum contributes to the economic development of the Kyrgyz Republic through the delivery of microfinance services in rural and urban areas that lead to increased employment and meet the interests of its clients and investors.

location.town: Bagong Silang, Iligan City, Lanao del Norte

loans.name: Josefina

texts.en:
To make a better living, Josefina owns and operates a business where she raises pigs to sell. She has been engaged in her business for over 15 years and earns good profits from the income generated by these activities.

In 1997, Josefina joined ASHI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and to have the ability to engage in business activities. Josefina has successfully repaid a previous loan from ASHI and she received a 100% credit rating. This previous loan was used to purchase livestock feed and other supplies.

Josefina is requesting a new loan of 44,000 PHP which will be used to purchase livestock feed and additional piglets so she can earn more revenue. This will be the tenth loan taken out by Josefina from ASHI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve and expand her business. This will allow Josefina to grow her hog raising business further so that her four children can fulfill their dreams of managing their own business someday. Josefina wants to give her family a decent life.

Josefina's long term goal is to continue to build her secondary fishing business. She wants to purchase additional raw materials for her fishing business so she can expand it. This will allow her to sell more fish in the local community and in the surrounding neighborhoods. She also hopes to have successful pig farm someday.

loans.name: Yntymak

texts.en:
Yntymak I. is a resident of Tup, a small town in the Isykul region with a population of 15,000 people. Yntymak is just eighteen years old and is engaged in cattle breeding. Two years ago, his uncle presented him with a calf on his birthday. After fattening, Yntymak resold that calf at a higher price and, since that moment, he has been breeding cattle. With the loan he wants to purchase a calf for fattening and resale to make some money. In the future, he wants to increase the number of cattle he has and he plans to go to university.

--- Where Did This Loan Come From? ---

 This loan is brought to you by Mol Bulak Finance (MBF), a young, ambitious and socially-focused Microfinance Institution in Kyrgyzstan. 
MBF is strongly committed to the principles of sustainable development and upholds the triple bottom line – People (building human capital and taking care of its customers as well as society), Planet (keeping environmentally friendly) and Profit (earning revenue to expand autonomously). MBF is the only Microfinance Institute in Kyrgyzstan that delivers its services to customers 365 days a year. To learn more about MBF and view a Video presentation about the organization, please visit: http://www.kiva.org/about/aboutPartner?id=135 
If you would like to support and learn more about Kyrgyzstan and microfinance in Central Asia, please join our Lending Team - Supporters of Kyrgyzstan – Mol Bulak Finance at http://kiva.org/team/kyrgyzstan. Members will get special updates and news from Kiva Fellows in Kyrgyzstan and from the MBF staff.

loans.use: to purchase a calf

loans.name: Miguela

texts.en:
For almost 14 years of her membership in ASHI, Miguela M. has been a model member dedicated to managing her family’s operations.
 
Miguela is 43 years old and married to Eduardo, who is 41 years old and a fisherman. She has four minor-aged children and lives in Talim Island, Rizal province, in the Philippines. She is a God-fearing and courageous mother. She and her husband have helped each other to overcome the poverty that impeded their family. 

In 1996, Miguela joined Kiva partner, ASHI (Ahon Sa Hirap, Inc.), an MFI in the Philippines, in order to acquire capital for her fishing business and embark on her bamboo set (furniture-making) business. As a member of ASHI for almost 14 years, she has a remarkably good performance in her credit rating and is therefore being trusted by ASHI to obtain larger loans. 

This loan is her ninth – she has made good use of her previous loans to expand her business and income. Miguela has applied for a new loan of 25,000 Philippine pesos to buy fishing nets, a fish cage and other supplies. The remaining money will be used in her business of making bamboo sets (furniture).

Miguela dreams of expanding her business into a full-fledged fish farm. She also dreams of sending her five children to school until they finish college and find good jobs. Until that dreams happens, she is happy with the way in which ASHI and Kiva have changed her family's life and given them a good possibility of making their dreams come true.

loans.use: To buy fishing nets, a fish cage and other supplies. The remaining money will be used to make bamboo sets (furniture)

loans.name: Chai Bora Group

texts.en:
Magreth C., age 36, is single with three children who are 16, 14 and 12 years old.  She has operated a retail shop for one and a half years now.  She works from 6 am to 8:30 pm daily and she is able to make a monthly profit of about $186.

This will be Magreth’s second motisha loan from Tujijenge Tanzania.  A motisha loan is a product offered by Tujijenge Tanzania that allows borrowers with good credit ratings to pay back their original loans faster and receive extra money before their original loan term has ended.  She used the previous motisha loan to increase her business stock and she has paid back the loan successfully. She hopes for a new motisha loan to continue to increase her stock.  Her dream is to buy a fridge and start selling juice, water and soda.
	
Magreth will share this loan with her loan group.  Chai Bora has nine members. The members of the group will hold each other accountable in paying back the loan. 

In the picture, Magreth is first one on the left, standing in the second row.

loans.use: To increase her stock

loans.name: Sop

texts.en: Mrs. Sop S., age 58, sells both used and new clothes at the local busy market. From this, she is able to earn $5 a day to support her family. She doesn’t have a life partner as her husband divorced her when her child was very small. Now her child is grown and can support the family by selling a few groceries. Recently, Sop S. sold nearly all of her clothes to her buyers and she wants to replenish her stock but she lacks capital. She is, therefore, asking for a loan in order to buy more clothes to resell.

loans.use: To buy more clothes to resell.

loans.name: Felomina

texts.en: Felomina J. is 39 years old and resides in Binangonan, which is located in the Province of Rizal. She lives with her husband, who works as a laborer, and their five dependent children. Felomina has a store in her house where she sells basic necessities and all types of products that people use in their homes. She is requesting a loan so that she can have the funds needed to buy more food products and basic household necessities. This will allow her to attract more customers and increase her sales. Felomina’s business is very important because it enables her to provide better financial stability for her family to live in a decent manner. She hopes to provide them with everything necessary to move forward against poverty. Felomina dreams of the best for her family: to have expanded business and to have a happy family.  She has shown herself to be hard working and strong-minded to make her dreams come true. She hopes that her business will continue to be more productive and improve the overall quality of life for her entire family.

loans.use: To buy more food products and basic necessities for her store.

loans.name: Ngô

texts.en:
O. Ngô Thị (20209050022) is a 38-year-old female living in the town of Huyện Yên Phong - Tỉnh Bắc Ninh.  She is married and has two school-aged children.  To make a living, O. owns & operates a food stall selling sweets & confectionaries such as cookies & cakes in the local community.  O. has been engaged in this business for over 18 years and earns approximately 4,200,000 VND a month from these activities.


In 2008, O. joined SEDA to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities.  O. has successfully repaid a previous loan of 5,600,000 VND from SEDA.  This previous loan was used to purchase additional products to sell.  O. is now requesting a new loan of 8,288,000 VND, which will be used to purchase a transport vehicle to improve the business.  The loan will be the fourth loan taken out by O. from SEDA.  O. plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve the general living conditions of her family.


About SEDA:

The mission of SEDA (Center of Small Enterprise Development Assistance) is to provide microfinance services to the low income and disadvantaged people in rural areas of Hanoi and the Northern provinces of Vietnam.


*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in Vietnamese while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.


O. Ngô Thị (20209050022) là 38 tuổi nữ.  Cô ấy sống ở thành phố huyện Yên Phong - tỉnh Bắc Ninh.  Cô ấy đã lập gia đình và có 2 trẻ ở độ tuổi đi học.  Để kiếm sống, O. Sở hữu và thực hiện hoạt động kinh dO..  Công việc kinh dO. hoạt động tại lĩnh vực thực phẩm.  Mục đích chính của việc kinh dO. là buôn bán quầy thực phẩm.  Trong khi không phải chỉ có các phương thức tạo nên thu nhập, mà nguồn thu nhập chính của công việc kinh dO. chủ yếu từ bán các loại bánh kẹo như bánh quy & bánh ngọt trong cộng đồng địa phương.  O. thực hiện công việc kinh dO. này trong hơn 18 năm.  Từ các hoạt động này, O. kiếm được khoảng 4.200.000 VND một tháng.


Vào 2008, O. đã tham gia SEDA để có thể tiếp cận với các dịch vụ tài chính giúp cải thiện  sinh hoạt và khả năng tham gia vào các hoạt động kinh dO. của cô ấy/ anh ấy.  O. đề nghị khoản vay lần đầu tiên từ SEDA.  Khoản vay trước đây được sử dụng mua các sản phẩm bổ sung để bán.  Cô ấy hiện đang đề nghị một khoản vay mới là 8.288.000 VND.  Khoản vay hiện tại sẽ được sử dụng để mua phương tiện vận chuyển để cải thiện công việc kinh dO..  Khoản vay sẽ là 4th khoản vay của người vay từ SEDA.  O. dự định sẽ sử dụng nguồn thu nhập bổ sung từ công việc kinh dO.  cải thiện điều kiện sống chung của gia đình người vay.


Về SEDA:

Nhiệm vụ của SEDA (Trung Tâm hỗ Trợ Phát Triển các DO. Nghiệp Nhỏ) là cung cấp các dịch vụ tài chính vi mô cho những người có thu nhập thấp và kém may mắn trong các vùng nông thôn tại Hà Nội và các tỉnh phía Bắc Việt Nam

*Lưu ý: Để phát huy tối đa hiệu quả & giảm chi phí, khoản vay này đã được thông báo bằng biểu mẫu để có thể được Kiva tự động biên dịch. .  Do việc biên dịch thủ công các danh mục rất tốn kém, nên Kiva đã tạo biểu mẫu này cho phần Field Partner (Trường Đối Tác) cho phép họ tiếp tục thông báo các khoản vay bằng  Vietnamese trong khi cung cấp thông tin có chất lượng & chính xác cho người cho vay Kiva.  .

S. faced a problem: she and her husband always go to work by hiring a taxi at a high price or by walking. They dream of having their own vehicle, but their dreams do not come true because they don't have enough money to buy a motorbike. In addition to their savings, S. is looking for a loan in order to purchase a new motorbike that she will use to commute to work.

He plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand his business. 

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is one of the accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To repair a transport vehicle used in the business

loans.name: Gilda

texts.en:
Gilda B. is from the village of South Cogon, Misamis Oriental. She is 52 years old. Gilda is married and has three adult children. To make a living, Gilda owns & operates a sari-sari (variety) retail shop selling both food & daily use products in the local community. Gilda has been engaged in her business for over 10 years and earns approximately 7,000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2009, Gilda joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Gilda has successfully repaid a previous loan of 5,000 PHP from HSPFI. This previous loan was used to purchase additional products to sell. Gilda is requesting a new loan of 5,000 PHP, which will be used to purchase additional inventory & working capital. This loan will be the third loan taken out by Gilda from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand her business. 

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is one of the accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase additional inventory & working capital

loans.name: Kov

texts.en:
Mrs. Kov M. is 58 years old and married. She lives in an old wooden home with family members in a village in Phnom Penh Capital and also owns a piece of farmland that she inherited many years ago from her grandparents. She uses this land to grow different kinds of crops, which she and her husband work on.
The couple is blessed with four children who are married. Kov M. has an older house that is surrounded by pollution affecting her health and her daily living conditions. In order to resolve the problem, Kov M. has applied for a loan to repair and decorate her house. Mrs. Kov M. was not available at that time so her husband is pictured instead.

loans.use: To repair and decorate her home

loans.name: Letecia

texts.en:
Letecia F. is from the village of South Cogon, Misamis Oriental. She is 44 years old and married with four school-aged children. To make a living, Letecia owns and operates a multi-cab service business in the local community, with her husband acting as driver. Letecia has been engaged in her business for over three years and earns approximately 8000 PHP a month from these activities.

In 2009, Letecia joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. She has successfully repaid a previous loan of 7000 PHP from HSPFI, which was used to invest in expanding the business. Letecia is requesting a new loan of 4000 PHP which will be used to purchase materials needed to provide business services. This loan will be the third loan taken out by Letecia from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve and expand her business. 

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is one of accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase materials needed to provide multi-cab service

loans.name: Am

texts.en: Am S. is 23 years old and owns a wooden house and grocery shop, selling many items, including cooking ingredient, sweets, soft drink and gasoline. Am S. sells her inventory to people passing by and her neighbors. She has been running a grocery store for some time and earns an average of $4 a day. To provide their family with financial stability, her husband works in construction. This couple have a young child living with them who attends school. Am S. will be using this loan to buy a plot of land, where she will plant crops to generate extra money.

loans.use: To buy a plot of land to plant crops

loans.name: Treas

texts.en:
Mr. K. has been spending his life cultivating crops, which is a skill he learned from his grandparent when he was young. He is now married and has four school-aged kids. His wife frequently works in the farm fields alongside him.

Growing crops is an annual action with which K. has had great success. He is able to plant the crops at least twice a year by following both rainy and dry seasons. The growing season is approaching and he is pursuing a loan of $800 to be used to grow green beans.

loans.use: To grow green beans

loans.name: Oyunbileg

texts.en:
Oyunbileg N. is 26 years old and lives with her husband and mother in Bayanhongor province, central Mongolia. They live in their own ger, a traditional nomadic housing tent.

Oyunbileg operates a noodle-making shop with the help of her husband. She and her husband began the business in 2007 after purchasing noodle-producing equipment with 1,500,000 MNT. Since then, they have been operating their business sustainably and actively.

The two would like to keep growing their business and be able to increase production types so that this business will be popular among their customers. Oyunbileg is requesting a 2,500,000 MNT loan in order to purchase equipment and more flour used in the production of noodles.

Oyunbileg hopes to create her own noodle factory in her town in the future.

loans.use: To purchase equipment and more flour

loans.name: Kheng

texts.en:
R. is a 35-year-old village woman who has had a job as a rice farmer since she was single. In addition, she currently sells fresh fish that she gets from her wholesale supplier and from fishermen. She runs her business in the market and earns approximately of $3 a day. Her husband frequently works in the farm fields alongside her.

R. needs a loan as additional capital for her fish-selling business. Any remaining money she will use towards the planting of rice crops.

loans.use: To use as additional capital for her fish-selling and rice-farming businesses

loans.name: Bayartogtoh

texts.en:
Bayartogtoh D. is 29 years old and lives with his wife and two-year-old son in Bayanhongor province, central Mongolia. He and his family live together in a ger, a traditional Mongolian nomadic tent. His son goes to a local kindergarten while his wife Naranjargal is currently unemployed and helps him with his business. Bayartogtoh receives a 41,400 MNT per month disability pension.

Bayartogtoh suffered from a hip-joint bone injury when he was young, but it does not affect his wood-products business. He began his business in 2005 after attending a carpentry certificate training course. He owns and manages a ger and his furniture business, supplying his customers’ orders and needs.  He is requesting a 500,000 MNT loan to purchase more wood and supplies in order to expand his business and keep up with customers’ orders.

Bayartogtoh would like one day to open a small factory in which he can produce even more products with ease.

loans.use: To purchase more wood and supplies

loans.name: Yut

texts.en: Yut S., 49 years old, owns a small shop located inside a secondary school where she sells various cakes to the student. She typically makes around US$ 2 in profit each day to ensure that her family has a comfortable life. Another source of family income comes from her husband’s job, who is a professional teacher. Yut S. has a piece of farmland, on which she hopes to plant a rice crop to provide food for the family and to sell. Because she doesn’t have capital, Yut S. is requesting a loan to buy fertilizer, insecticide, and rice seed for farming.

loans.use: To buy fertilizer, insecticide, and rice seed for farming.

loans.name: Gan-Ulzii

texts.en:
Gan-Ulzii H. is 27 years old and lives with his wife and two children in Hentiy province, eastern of Mongolia. He and his family live in a ger, which is a traditional Mongolian housing tent. Gan-Ulzii operates a wooden products trading business at the regional market in his province with the help of his wife. He has operated in this trade for the last 3 years and has become quite experienced. Gan-Ulzii is very skillful and his customers are very satisfied with his wooden products. His monthly production ranges from 3 to 4 wooden doors of ger and 1 to 2 wooden door of houses which earn constant sales revenues of approximately 500,000 MNT. 

His business is very important to his family life as a source of family income. Gan-Ulzii is a hardworking, optimistic, modest person who is keen on helping to others. He dislikes being an " idle hand" and always seeks to do something productive for his work and life. He says, “My children are still young, so I need to begin saving for their future education.” He is requesting a 500,000 MNT loan to purchase an old house in order to reuse its wood for his business.

loans.use: To purchase an old house

loans.name: Seang

texts.en: Mrs. Seang T. has been in the farming business for years. She plants rice crops on her own land, from which she earns a living. Her husband assists her with the farm work. Seang T. has been married for years and has five teenage children. Two are employed at the construction field and the other three are going to school. The coming heavy rainfall is good for growing; Seang T. is looking for assistance in order to help support her in the farm business.

loans.use: To help support her in the farm business.

loans.name: Myagmarjav

texts.en:
Myagmarjav J. is 52 years old and lives with her husband in Hentiy province, eastern Mongolia. All her children have been living separately from their parents.  Her husband helps Myagmarjav with her business, where she sews ger (traditional Mongolian housing tent) covers and other items. She started her business in 2009 by hand-making all of her products.

Myagmarjav has gained many years of sewing experience since she used to work as a seamstress for a local company. Her main products are ger covers made of canvas and tarpaulin cotton.  Myagmarjav sells them out of a local market in her town. Her business is advantageous and beneficial because there are not many similar business owners in her town. "I had been working under the supervision of someone else for many years, but now I am feeling happy that I am working and earning for myself," she says.

Myagmarjav is requesting a 800,000 MNT loan to purchase materials which can be used to help her sewing business.

loans.use: To purchase inventory

loans.name: Anonymous

texts.en: The Kiva borrower is a 32-year old single man from Lebanon. He is living with his parents and one brother. He is working as a plumber, installing toilets, faucets, etc. He has been involved in this occupation for the past 5 years. This will be his second loan and he said that the first loan amount was sufficient to fulfill his business objectives for the past year. He also says that his business productivity and income have increased as a result of the loan. He has been very reliable with his repayments to Ameen and has actually repaid his loan in full several months early. He is asking for a larger loan amount of $1,400 to purchase merchandise needed in order to expand his business and pursue more work and more projects. Note: Based on the political and social challenges of Lebanon, personally identifiable attributes of this entrepreneur have been altered to protect him or her (i.e. blacking out portions of the entrepreneur in his picture, not indicating hisname and location, etc.). Ameen s.a.l. appreciates Kiva lenders' understanding of these challenges and encourages lenders to continue their support for Lebanon's borrowers. About Ameen: Ameen s.a.l. has been a major player in the Lebanese Microfinance sector since 1999. Originally a micro-credit program created by CHF International, Ameen evolved to become Ameen s.a.l. in 2003, a Lebanese services company. In 2007, Ameen s.a.l. registered with the Central Bank of Lebanon to become the first Lebanese financial institution specializing in microfinance. At Ameen s.a.l. we pledge to provide financial services to the largest number of micro and small entrepreneurs and to the working poor, to help them develop their businesses and improve their incomes. Ameen has been able to use its interest-free loans from Kiva to offer lower-interest loans with faster disbursement for their micro-loan borrowers. Since its inception, Ameen has provided high-quality financial services to over 41,000 borrowers and disbursed over 81,000 loans totaling $115 million. To learn more about Ameen, please visit partners.kivaorg/partners/115

loans.use: To purchase merchandise

loans.name: Meas

texts.en:
The woman shown in the picture is Mrs. Meas E..  She lives in a wooden house. She built a small store where she sells dessert and cake to the villagers for a profit.

She is married to Tong Kheng, age 31, who shares responsibility for his family by selling wooden beds. Meas E. has an older wooden house which needs repairs, so Meas E. will be using her first loan to mend and decorate it.

loans.use: To mend and decorate her old house.

loans.name: Kabaranga Development, Kihihi Group

texts.en:
In the Custom trading centre of Kihihi, exists a hard working and determined K. Godfrey who has been running a produce business for a period of over 6 years where he sells food stuffs. As a matter of fact, his hard work and friendly character have brought him this far alongside his other business of selling  milk which all together earns him 120,000 Ugandan shillings monthly. 

This loan will help Godfrey buy a better quality of product  like; rice, beans, coffee and to restock in larger quanity in order to meet the customers demand. With an improved business, he will be able to earn more revenue and improve his family's lifestyle, as he struggles to educate his 9 children to make them better people in the future.

loans.use: To purchase more food products like beans and coffee for resale

loans.name: Mohamed Alieu

texts.en:
Mohamed is 24 years old and is married with twelve dependents. He started business selling foodstuffs, when he lost his job. He later changed to selling pharmaceutical drugs, which he has done for the past five years. His pharmacy is located in the main lorry (truck) park in Makeni city.

Mohamed has a very good loan repayment history. He needs a loan of 4,000,000 SLL to pay the rent for his pharmacy and to buy more pharmaceutical drugs to sell. He intends to use the proceeds of this loan to educate his family members and buy a house.

loans.use: To pay rent for his pharmacy and to buy more essential drugs

loans.name: Nhik

texts.en:
Nhik V. has been in the farming business for years. She plants various crops to earn a living and typically generates an income of $2 per day.

Nhik V.’s husband died of senility years ago. She currently has four children, two of whom are married while the other two are single. To help solve her family’s financial crisis, three of her children are employed.

Nhik V. lacks the money to grow rice crops during the coming farming season; this is why she has applied for a $300 loan from Kiva.

loans.use: To grow rice crops

loans.name: Misirat's Group

texts.en: Misirat K. is the leader of this group. She is 55 and married with two sons. Her older son went to Russia to work to make some money and the second is engaged in cattle breeding. Having saved some money, Misirat and her husband bought a bull and resold it at a higher price after fattening. With that profit Misirat purchased a cow and a calf. She also sells milk every day and in this way she makes 2,000 soms per month. With the loan, Misirat wants to purchase a cow for breeding. Gulaiym N., 27, is married and has two daughters and a son. Her older daughter is in school while the others are not yet schooling. In order to make money Gulaiym breeds cattle and her husband works as a truck driver. Ten years ago, with the initial investment of 8,000 soms, she bought a calf and, since that time, she started to breed cattle. She applied for the loan because she wants to purchase a cow in order to increase the number of her cattle. In the future she plans to repair her house. Janyshbek A., 26, is married and has a two-year-old daughter. In order to make money, Janyshbek breeds cattle and also transports various fruits and vegetables to Bishkek to sell. He applied for the loan because he needs money to purchase potatoes which he plans to transport to Bishkek to sell. Mahbubahan A. is the treasurer of the group. She is 51 and married with three daughters and a son. Two older daughters are married and live separately with their families, the son went to Russia to work and the youngest daughter helps with housework. Mahbubahan breeds cattle and also sells dairy products, making 2,200 soms per month. With the loan, she wants to purchase a calf for breeding. In the future she plans to increase the number of her cattle and save money to be able to pay for her children’s university education. --- Where Did This Loan Come From? --- This loan is brought to you by Mol Bulak Finance, a young and ambitious socially-focused MFI in Kyrgyzstan. Mol Bulak Finance is strongly committed to the principles of sustainable development on the basis of the 3-Ps concept - People (building human capital and taking care of its customers and the society as well), Profit (to be profitable in order to grow further) and the Planet (taking care of the environment). It is also the only MFI in Kyrgyzstan that delivers its services to customers 365 days a year. To learn more about Mol Bulak and view a video presentation about the organization, please visit: www.kiva.org/about/aboutPartner?id=135. If you would like to support and learn more about Kyrgyzstan and micro-finance in Central Asia, please join our Lending Team - Supporters of Kyrgyzstan - at www.kiva.org/team/kyrgyzstan. Members will get special updates and news from the Kiva Fellows in Kyrgyzstan and from Mol Bulak staff.

loans.use: To purchase a cow for breeding

loans.name: Bugembe Katwe Women's Group, Jinja

texts.en:
Good planning in any kind of business adventure is the easiest means to achieving one’s clear set objectives in the short or long run. This is a reality that 58-year-old B. George embraced 34 years ago in Jinja Town. Achieving this business longevity has not come easy for him, however, as he has had to fight off many problems along the way.

George, a married father of six, also relies on profits from a rental business to supplement the 200,000 shillings he earns from his main retail business where he has, for the most part, been selling mattresses and other home products like plastics and cutlery. This business was gotten on its feet with savings from his poultry business.

With this loan, George says he wants to buy more mattresses to sell.

loans.use: To purchase more mattresses to sell

loans.name: Maksat

texts.en: Maksat A. is married and has one daughter. He was born in Bokso-Zhol village in a large family and spent most of his time helping his parents in the household, watching his younger siblings, and farming. After graduating from secondary school, Maksat served in the army and, after returning home, he got a job as an inspector in a local power station. Ten years ago, using his earned savings of 15,000 Kyrgyz soms, he started up his business of cattle breeding. In 2003, Maksat moved to Kara-Balta town near the capital, Bishkek, with his daughter and wife, who came to work as a nurse. Taking into account that farming is the major means of subsistence of Maksat’s family and his elderly parents, he spends a lot of time improving his farm. Being a persistent and hard-working man, he has developed his farm and presently has five milk cows, twenty sheep, and one horse. Maksat plans to use this loan of 35,000 Kyrgyz soms to broaden his sheep business. In future, he dreams of buying a car and renovating his house. About Bai-Tushum and Partners: Bai-Tushum and Partners uses Kiva funding to target the especially vulnerable members of the population. It is one of the leading microfinance institutions in Kyrgyzstan. As a reliable financial partner, it contributes to the economic development of the Kyrgyz Republic through the delivery of microfinance services in rural and urban areas that lead to increased employment and meet the interests of its clients and investors.

loans.use: To broaden his sheep business

loans.name: Seydou

texts.fr:
Natif de Koutiala, Monsieur Seydou C. est âgé de 30 ans,  mariée et père de 3 enfants. Il est polygame et vit avec ses femmes et ses enfants dans le quartier  Darsalam II de la ville de Koutiala (Région de Sikasso).  
Il n’a pas fréquenté l’école pour des raisons sociales, c’est ainsi qu’il embrassa les activités génératrices de revenus auprès de son père depuis son jeune  âge et l’exerce pour lui-même il y a 10 ans.  Il est très bien sollicité par ses clients,  car les friperies sont moins coûteuses et sont de  meilleure qualité très appréciée au Mali. 
Pour la bonne satisfaction de sa clientèle, Monsieur C. a fait recours à   l’institution de microfinance Soro Yiriwaso avec qui il est à son  premier prêt.  
Avec ce prêt  il compte acheter, 5 balles de friperies au Burkina Faso. Il effectue sa vente au grand marché de Koutiala sous son hangar, à une clientèle constituée de femmes et d’hommes essentiellement au comptant. 
Avec ce financement, il compte sur un bénéfice mensuel de 100 000 FCFA  pour subvenir à ses besoins à savoir le remboursement du prêt, satisfaire les charges de la famille et investir le reste dans son activité. 
Dans les jours à venir, il envisage agrandir son activité pour attirer plus de clients.
texts.en:
A native of Koutiala, Mr. Seydou C. is 30 years old, married and the father of 3 children. He is polygamous and lives with his wives and children in the Darsalam II neighborhood of Koutiala (Sikasso Region). He did not attend school for social reasons. Thus, he took up his father's line of business at a young age and has operated it for himself for 10 years. He is much sought after by his customers because the less costly and better quality second-hand clothing is much appreciated in Mali. In order to satisfy customer demand, Mr. C. turned to the Soro Yiriwaso microfinance institution, where he has his first loan. He plans to buy 5 bales of second-hand clothing at Burkina Faso with this loan. He conducts his sales principally in cash at the large market in Koutiala under his shed roof to a clientele composed of women and men. With this loan, he expects to make a monthly profit of 100,000 CFA to support himself; namely, to repay the loan, to provide for his family and to invest the rest in his business. In the future, he plans to expand his buiness in order to attract more customers.

Translated from French by Connie Archea, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy second-hand clothing

loans.name: Anonymous Group
loans.use: To buy more bags of flour, sugar, onions, oil, and beans to sell

loans.name: Benkadi 1 Group

texts.fr:
Les huit membres du groupe Benkadi 1 sont des femmes mariées majoritairement dans des familles nucléaires avec en moyenne 42 ans et 3 enfants. Elles vivent toutes dans le village de Dougounikoro dans la commune rurale de Sanando, préfecture de Barouéli, dans la région de Ségou (4ème région administrative du Mali) et se sont connues à travers des liens de mariage, de voisinage et de parenté. 
Dans le but d’augmenter leurs superficies de culture, elles ont fait recours à Soro Yiriwaso et sont à leur 2ème cycle de prêt de campagne. 
Les membres du groupe vont cultiver l’arachide, le mil et le fonio.
Madame Nah S. compte utiliser son prêt pour acheter 25kg de semences d’arachide,  deux sacs de complexe céréale, 2 bidons d’herbicide et recruter la main d’œuvre pour les activités de labour et de récolte  pour son champ d’arachide. 
Elle se ravitaille en intrants agricoles à la foire de Konobougou, en main d’œuvre avec l’association des jeunes et des femmes du village. 
Avec une superficie de 2 hectares, elle espère produire 15 sacs d’arachide, 6 sacs de mil et 5 sacs de fonio. Une partie de la production est auto consommée tandis que le reste est vendu pour prendre en charge les besoins de condiments et de soins de santé des enfants. 
Madame Nah S. à l’image des autres femmes du groupe a pour objectif d’assurer l’auto suffisance alimentaire dans le village et faire de l’élevage des petits ruminants.
texts.en:
The eight members of the Benkadi 1 group are married women who mostly live in nuclear families. They are, on average, 42 years old and have three children. The all live in the rural town of Sanando, in the Barouéli prefecture, in the region of Ségou (the fourth administrative region of Mali). They know each other as neighbors and through marriage and family ties. With the goal of adding to their land to cultivate, they have joined Soro Yiriwaso and are on their second business loan cycle. The members of the group are going to cultivate peanuts, millet and fonio. Madame Nah S. plans to use her loan to buy 25 kg of peanuts seeds, two sacks of cereal fertilizer and two cans of herbicide, and to recruit labor to work in the fields and to harvest the peanuts. She gets her supply of fertilizers at the market in Konobougou, and her workers come from the youth association and the women of the village. With two hectares of land, she hopes to produce 15 sacks of peanuts, six sacks of millet and five sacks of fonio. Part of the harvest will be consumed within the family while the rest will be sold to pay for food and healthcare for her children. Madame Nah S., like the other women of the group, has the goal of becoming self sufficient with food and of raising small livestock.

Translated from French by Shannon Arnold, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase of fertilizer, peanut seeds, and herbicides, and to use labor for working the fields and harvesting.

loans.name: Bavawalala Development Group-Jinja

texts.en:
For the last six years Patrick M., a happily married 47-year-old father of two, has brought hard work to bear in the poultry-selling business that he operates from Buwenda-Jinja. Such an enterprise is a very worthwhile undertaking considering the high profits that can be earned.

After completing his national agro advisory services apprentice course, Patrick felt it would be a good time to establish another business in addition to his farming operation. While maintaining his farming activities, he devotes more time to his poultry sales, earning profits that add up to 40,000 shillings. Patrick is now requesting a loan to buy more layer chickens in order to expand the business.

loans.use: The purchase of more layer chickens

loans.name: Benkadi  2 Group

texts.fr:
Les six  femmes du groupe Benkadi 2  sont mariées majoritairement dans des grandes familles polygames avec en moyenne 34 ans et 3 enfants. Elles vivent toutes dans le village de Dougounikoro dans la commune rurale de Sanando, préfecture de Barouéli, dans la région de Ségou (4ème région administrative du Mali) et se sont connues à travers des liens de mariage et de parenté. 
Dans le but d’augmenter leurs superficies de culture, elles ont fait recours à Soro Yiriwaso et sont à leur 2ème cycle de prêt de campagne. 
L’arachide, le mil et le fonio sont des spéculations que les membres du groupe vont cultiver.
Madame Tata D. compte utiliser son prêt pour acheter deux sacs de complexe céréale, 2 bidons d’herbicide et recruter la main d’œuvre pour les activités de labour et de récolte  dans ses champs. Elle se ravitaille en intrants agricoles à la foire de Konobougou, en main d’œuvre avec l’association des jeunes et des femmes du village. 
Avec une superficie de 2,50 hectares, elle espère produire 10 sacs de mil et 8 sacs de fonio. Une partie de la production est auto consommée tandis que le reste est vendu pour prendre en charge les frais de condiments, les fournitures scolaires et les soins de santé des enfants. 
Madame Tata D. compte réaliser 70.000FCFA en fin de campagne.
texts.en:
The six women of the Benkadi 2 group are married and most live in large polygamous families. They average 34 years of age and three children each. They all live in the village of Dougounikoro in the rural commune of Sanando, Barouéli prefecture, in the Ségou region (4th administrative region of Mali) They know each other through marriage and kinship ties. With the goal of increasing their cultivable land, they turned to Soro Yiriwaso and are on their second planting loan cycle. The group members will grow peanuts, millet and fonio (a species of millet). Mrs. Tata D. plans to use her loan to buy two bags of complex fertilizer and to recruit the labor for ploughing and harvesting the fields. She obtains fresh agricultural supplies at the market in Konobougou and labor from the village association of young people and women. She hopes to produce 10 bags of millet and 8 bags of fonio on 2.50 hectares of land. One part of the harvest is consumed by the family while the rest is sold to provide for the costs of seasonings, school supplies and the children’s health care. Mrs. D. expects to make 70,000 CFA by the end of the crop year.

Translated from French by Connie Archea, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To pay for complex fertilizer, herbicides and labor for ploughing and harvesting.

loans.name: Akibathon's Group

texts.en:
Akibathon B. is the leader of the group. She is 50 and divorced. She has raised three sons; the older son works as a layer, the second is a driver, and the youngest works in construction.  Akibathon works as a nurse, and she also owns a plot of land and cultivates cotton.  She has been doing it for 19 years and selling the cotton she makes for about 4000 soms per month.  With money received from the loan, Akibathon wants to purchase fertilizers for farming. In the future she wants to purchase another plot of land and build a house for her sons.

Hosiyathon Y., 45, is married. She has two sons and a daughter. The first son and the husband work in construction, the second studies at university, and the daughter is at school. In order to make money, Hosiyathon sells milk. Every day she sells about eight liters (10 soms a liter). She also breeds livestock, selling some sheep after fattening, Hosiyathon makes 4000 soms per month.  With money received from the loan she wants to purchase sheep for breeding.  In the future she plans to increase the number of livestock, buy a plot of land, and build a house for her older son.

Ashirhon K. , 37, is married. She has two daughters and a son, and all of them are students. Ashirhon works as a nurse and her husband works in construction. Nineteen years ago, Ashirhon and her husband sold their harvest and with that money they bought sheep for breeding. Selling some sheep after fattening, they makes 5000 som per month. Ashirhon applied for the loan because she needs money to purchase sheep to increase the number of livestock.

Zumrathon N. is the treasurer of the group.  She is 47 and married. She has a son and three daughters. Her son and her husband work in construction, and they earn 4000 soms per month.  The older daughter works in a pharmacy, and the other daughters study at school. Fifteen years ago, having saved some money, Zumrathon and her husband started to breed livestock.  Selling sheep after fattening at a higher price, Zumrathon makes 4000 soms per month. With money received from the loan, she wants to purchase sheep for breeding.  

--- Where Did This Loan Come From? ---

 This loan is brought to you by Mol Bulak Finance (MBF), a young, ambitious and socially-focused Microfinance Institution in Kyrgyzstan. 
MBF is strongly committed to the principles of sustainable development and upholds the triple bottom line – People (building human capital and taking care of its customers as well as society), Planet (keeping environmentally friendly) and Profit (earning revenue to expand autonomously). MBF is the only Microfinance Institute in Kyrgyzstan that delivers its services to customers 365 days a year. To learn more about MBF and view a Video presentation about the organization, please visit: http://www.kiva.org/about/aboutPartner?id=135 

If you would like to support and learn more about Kyrgyzstan and microfinance in Central Asia, please join our Lending Team - Supporters of Kyrgyzstan – Mol Bulak Finance at http://kiva.org/team/kyrgyzstan. Members will get special updates and news from Kiva Fellows in Kyrgyzstan and from the MBF staff.

loans.use: to purchase fertilizers

loans.name: Yawa Angèle

texts.fr: K. est une femme mariée et mère d'un enfant. elle vit avec son mari et son époux  dans le quartier de akodessewa qui est un quartier périphérique de la ville de Lomé, elle a commencé ce commerce en 2006, sa clientèle se compose de toutes personnes. elle souhaite se réapprovisionner face à son stock en baisse raison pour laquelle elle sollicite de WAGES un crédit pour l'achat de  divers produits d'alimentation générale. avec son revenu elle participe aux dépenses de sa famille.
texts.en:
Yawa K. is married with one child and lives with her husband in the Akodessewa quarter which is on the outskirts of the town of Lomé. She created her business in 2006, and her customer base is varied. She would like to boost her inventory and so is seeking a loan from WAGES in order to purchase more food products. She will use her revenue to see to her family's needs.

Translated from French by Danielle Treharne, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchasing general foods

loans.name: Ablayo

texts.fr: cette femme a appris le métier de la couture, après sa formation, elle a ouvert en 2006 son propre atelier de couture qu'elle a appelé "CREATION DICO", elle confectionne bien les habits ce qui lui permet d'avoir tout le temps des demandes de sa clientèle. le matériel de couture qu'elle utilise est épuisé, elle sollicite un  prêt pour acheter des fils, des aiguilles,des grippures et divers.
texts.en:
This lady became a seamstress and after her training opened her own sewing studio in 2006; she named it "CREATION DICO". She makes dresses and always completes her customers' requests in time. The fabric that she uses has run out and so she is seeking a loan in order to buy thread, needles, and other items.

Translated from French by Danielle Treharne, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchasing sewing materials

loans.name: Tamara

texts.en:
Tamara Hovannisyan is from the village of Horom in the Shirak region of Armenia.  She is married with three children. Her daughter is 14 years old and her two sons are 21 and 19 years old.  Tamara has a high school diploma.  She has been self-employed in farming for the past 20 years.  She considers herself a hard worker and has a dream of renovating her house and establishing a small shop to support her family.  She is looking for a loan to purchase fuel and cattle feed to support her small livestock business.  

If successful, she expects her income to increase by 25% from her business loan.  In addition to supporting the education of her children, she also provides her brother’s family with agricultural produce grown on her farm.  She really enjoys living in Horom as she and her family like working the land.  She has chosen to expand her business so the family can continue living in their village of Horom.

loans.use: fuel and cattle feed

loans.name: Tene

texts.fr: M. est une femme très dynamique, elle exerce comme activité génératrice de revenu le commerce des habits et des sacs de dames. elle  exerce ce commerce depuis 5 ans déjà au marché local d'akodessewa, elle s'approvisionne dans les marchés locaux de lomé. son stock est en baisse , elle veut se réapprovisionner et sollicite de WAGES un crédit pour acheter une trentaine d'habits pour gonfler son stock. elle est mariée et mère d'un enfant.
texts.en:
M. is a very dynamic woman and makes money by selling women's dresses and bags. She has been doing this for five years at the local market in Akodessewa. She sources her goods from the local markets in Lomé. Her stock levels are low and so she is seeking a loan from WAGES in order to purchase around thirty dresses to boost her product offer. She is married with one child.

Translated from French by Danielle Treharne, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchasing women's dresses and bags

loans.name: Alexsan

texts.en:
Alexsan is from the village of Haykavan in the Shirak region.  He is particularly proud of his 20-year-old daughter who is planning to open a hairdressing shop in their village.  In order to support his daughter’s business ambitions, Alexsan has decided to expand his cattle breeding and vegetable growing businesses.  In order to grow his business, Alexsan is looking for a loan to purchase 2 calves and 6 lambs. 

With the loan Alexsan expects his income to grow by 20%.  Alexsan is married and also has an 18-year-old son.  He enjoys living in his village as he is surrounded by family and friends.  In Haykayan, raising cattle and growing vegetables is the best opportunity to have self-employment.  As he has worked in agriculture for 30 years, he is confident that he will succeed in growing his business.  Alexsan is a sincere worker and known for his pleasant personality.

loans.use: purchase 2 calves and 6 lambs

loans.name: Adodo Dédé

texts.fr: H. adodo dédé exerce comme activité génératrice de revenu le commerce de pagnes, elle a entamé ce commerce en 1990 et a associé plus tard le commerce de cartes de recharge. sa clientèle se compose de toutes personnes dont la plupart des femmes. elle voudrait se réapprovisionner raison pour laquelle elle sollicite de WAGES un crédit pour l'achat de d'une  quinzaine de pagnes de différentes qualités et de quelques cartes de recharges téléphoniques.
texts.en:
H. Adodo Dédé makes her living by selling wax cloths. She entered into this trade in 1990 and afterwards began selling phone topup cards as well. Her customer base is made up of many people, most of whom are women. She would like to replenish her stock and so is seeking a loan from WAGES so that she may buy fifteen wax cloths of varying quality as well as several phone topup cards.

Translated from French by Danielle Treharne, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchasing wax cloths

loans.name: Samvel

texts.en:
Samvel M. is from the village of Arevshat in the Shirak region of Armenia.  He is an honest hardworking person with 20 years of experience in farming.  Samvel is married with three children.  He has two daughters (10 and 11 years old) and a 7-year-old son. 

Samvel wishes some day to save enough funds to renovate the family house.  He is seeking a loan to purchase fertilizers to expand his vegetable growing business.  With the loan, Samvel expect to increase the family income by 25%.  Both Samvel and his wife like living in Arevshat because they are close to all their friends and extended family.  In addition to supporting his family, Samvel also helps his sick aunt with vegetables grown on his farm.  He expects success in his business due to his skills and the good quality of his farmland.

loans.use: fertilizers

loans.name: Jamoliddin

texts.en:
A. Jamoliddin is married and has three children whom he is very proud of since they are struggling to get ahead. With the faith that his children will be able to go to college to get ahead, he started a business of processing and selling dried apricots to be able to make enough money to pay for their schooling. He is experienced in this kind of business that allows him to expand his clientele day by day.

Right now Jamoliddin requests 5000 Somoni for purchasing apricots to  further process and to sell. With your help, Jamoliddin will be able to feel proud that through much effort, his children went to college and became honorable people.  

More about Tajikistan and IMON International

Tajikistan is known for its rich history, which includes a key post along the Silk Road and the end of Alexander the Great's rule. It has also produced great thinkers, philosophers, scientists and poets, including Rudaki, Avicenna, Ferdowsi, Omar Khayyam, Jomi, and Rumi. The country is home to communities that still speak the ancient Sogdian language, epic mountain passes, and a civilization that dates back to the 4th millennium BC. And, even today, it is a complex mixture of the Islamic faith, Soviet culture, New West culture and Central Asian traditions.

But Tajikistan is also the poorest of the former Soviet republics. The civil war, which ignited soon after its independence from the U.S.S.R., further damaged the already weak economy. In addition, 93% of the country is mountainous and only 7% of the land is arable. These conditions have resulted in high levels of unemployment and have forced hundreds of thousands to seek work in other countries, mainly Russia. While the people of Tajikistan are working to improve its agricultural production and manufacturing sector, nearly two-thirds of the population still live in abject poverty.

IMON's History

Since December 2007, IMON International has worked closely with Kiva and Kiva lenders to ensure that poor and low income clients represent a viable business proposition. Funds raised through Kiva have already been distributed to thousands of IMON International's clients and will continue to provide thousands more with permanent access to the varied financial services they need. To learn more about IMON International's work, please visit: www.imon.tj

loans.use: To buy apricots to expand his business

loans.name: Togetherness Group

texts.en:
Lusu L., who is holding the sign, is the leader of this group of five borrowers called Togetherness. Lusu is 29 years old, single, and has two children aged two months old and two years old. She also cares for one sibling.
Lusu is a university student. For the past eight years, she has been selling used clothes in Redlight Market, on the outskirts of Monrovia, Liberia. She plans to use her 6,000 LRD portion of this 30,000 LRD group loan to buy more bags of used clothes.
Lusu describes herself as a friendly woman. Her dreams are to improve her business and build a house.
In the photo that accompanies this profile, Michael G. is inset lower left because he was absent during the interview.

loans.use: To buy more bags of used clothes

loans.name: Parandzem

texts.en:
Parandzem M. is from the village of Arapni in the Shirak region. She is married with two children – a 25-year-old daughter and 28-year-old son. She has been working intensively in cattle breeding for the past ten years. Thorough her hard work she has now developed a successful microbusiness.  She has built a high quality cattle shed, which has improved the quality and health of her animals.  
At this time, Parandzem would like to expand her business. She is looking for a loan to purchase additional fuel and quality feed. She expects her business income to grow by 25 per cent with this loan. It is Parandzem’s dream to open a grocery shop in her village and she is always saving small amounts of money for this. Microfinance funding is convenient because she can receive services in her village of Arapni. Parandzem enjoys life in Arapni with her friends and family.

loans.use: animal feed and fuel

loans.name: Erkinjon

texts.en:
Erkinjon is 35 years old and the father of three children. His wife is a housekeeper and she supports him in everything he does. Erkinjon is a hardworking person and has been providing taxi services for six years. Most important to him is that his children go to university in the future, and that they finish it successfully so that they will have a better future as professionals.
Erkinjon wishes to keep his taxi business growing, and for this he needs to have his tools in good working order. He needs to buy spare parts to improve his car and that is why he is requesting a loan. Thanks to this work, Erkinjon has been able to stabilize his quality of life.

These conditions have resulted in high levels of unemployment and have forced hundreds of thousands of people to seek work in other countries, mainly Russia. Funds raised through Kiva have already been distributed to thousands of IMON International's clients and will continue to provide thousands more with permanent access to the varied financial services they need. To learn more about IMON International's work, please visit: www.imon.tj

loans.use: To purchase spare parts for repairing his car

loans.name: Khurshed

texts.en:
S. Khurshed is 34 years old, married, and has four children. His wife is a housekeeper and looks after their children. Khurshed is the only breadwinner in the family and he is really hardworking. He owns a café where he sells national meals and foodstuffs. He has been in this business for eight years. Khurshed tries to offer fresh foodstuffs and tasty meals in his café and ensure his customers can eat, have a rest and make any necessary purchases. His business is stable and this allows him to generate a significant income and ensure a good standard of living for his family.
Now Khurshed’s children are growing and the cost of raising them is growing, too. Therefore, Khurshed wants to improve his business in order to earn more money to cover his children's expenses. With this purpose in mind, he is requesting 4,500 TJS to expand his café.

To learn more about IMON International's work, please visit: www.imon.tj

loans.use: To expand his café business

loans.name: Artak

texts.en:
Artak M. is from the village of Karnout in the Shirak region of Armenia. He is married and lives with his extended family of six members. He has a beautiful two-year-old daughter. He considers himself a hardworker, and especially respects the senior members of his family and village. Artak wishes to build a new house for his whole family someday.
Artak has three years of experience growing vegetables and raising cattle. He is looking for a loan to purchase fuel and fertilizers to grow his business. With limited economic opportunities in his village growing his small business is his best opportunity. With his strong connections to his family, he wants to be able to stay in his village of Karnout. Life in Karnout is difficult, but Artak cannot picture living anywhere else.

loans.use: To purchase fuel and fertilizers

loans.name: Adjovi

texts.fr: adjovi s'est lancée en 2008 dans les activités de restauration, elle fait spécialement de la cuisine togolaise. beaucoup de gens viennent manger chez elle parce qu'elle fait de bons plats. actuellement les condiments et autres produits nécessaires à la restauration sont épuisés, elle sollicite donc chez WAGES un crédit pour l'achat de  divers condiments et de produits nécessaires à l'activité de la restauration. elle est célibataire, c'est avec le revenu de son commerce elle subvient à ses propres charges.
texts.en:
Adjovi entered the restaurant industry in 2008 and specializes in Togolese cuisine. Her restaurant is well frequented because she makes great dishes. Currently condiments and other products that are essential for her cooking have run out, and so she is seeking a loan from WAGES so that she can stock up on these items. She is single and uses the revenue from this business in order to see to household demands.

Translated from French by Danielle Treharne, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To purchase items necessary for her restaurant

loans.name: Raya

texts.en:
Raya S. is from the village of Horom in the Shirak region. She dreams of sending her two daughters (aged four and five years) to university one day. With this in mind, Raya has run a successful microbusiness for the past 15 years. She specializes in raising cattle and growing vegetables. In addition to saving for her children’s education, she also supports her extended family in Gyumi with vegetables grown on her farm.
At this time, Raya is ready to expand her business. She is looking for a loan to purchase additional livestock and expand her vegetable-growing business. With the loan, Raya is expecting her income to increase by 20 per cent. She is confident that her business plan will be successful. This is important to her as she wishes to be able to stay in her birthplace of Horom, surrounded by her friends and family.

loans.use: To purchase livestock

loans.name: Marina

texts.en:
Marina is married with two grown children. She is an entrepreneur from Novyi Rozdil, Stryi region. She sells print press in one of the local markets in her home town. Marina offers a variety of newspapers and magazines at affordable prices. She has been in this business for 12 years. Presently, Marina has 3,000 UAH invested in inventory. Her net profit amounts to 1,410 UAH per month.
Marina is a reliable borrower. She works hard to make her living and she likes to keep moving on. She is hoping to see her business grow in the future. One of her main goals is to open additional vending locations stocked with printed press inventory. Marina's merchandise sells well in Ukraine where people buy newspapers and magazines on a regular basis. She is seeking a loan of 3,000 UAH to increase her turnover capital.

loans.use: To increase turnover capital

loans.name: Akramjon

texts.en:
A. Akramjon is 37 years old, married, and has three children. He is a hardworking man struggling to feed his children by selling fabrics for national dresses. Akramjon has a trading place in the central local market of Dushanbe city. He tries to stock a wide range of goods to meet the requirements of his customers and satisfy the needs of customers with different levels of income.
Akramjon, a devoted father, is doing his utmost in order for his children to be well educated and happy. Today, he feels that with more working capital his business could generate more income, so he is asking for a loan of 6,000 TJS to jumpstart his business and raise his family's standard of living.

loans.use: To purchase new fabrics to increase his range of goods

loans.name: Telman

texts.en: Telman V. is from the village of Karnout in the Shirak region of Armenia.  He is married with four children.  Telman has two daughters (ages 20 and 22) and two sons (ages 25 and 28).  He has been engaged in agricultural production for the past 20 years.  He considers himself a hard worker and has developed a successful business raising cattle and growing vegetables.  He dreams to create a wholesale agricultural production farm to service the big cities someday.  Currently Telman is seeking a loan to grow his small  vegetable business by purchasing fertilizer.  He is expecting his income to increase by 10% with the loan.  He and his family really enjoy life in Karnout and, with continued business success, plan to permanently live here.  With the loan terms he has received he is optimistic his business plan will succeed.

loans.use: To buy fertilizer.

loans.name: Kurbonboy

texts.en:
Kurbonboy A. is a married father of four children. Faced with high unemployment in his country and the difficulty of finding a job, he began his own business selling men’s clothes. Fortunately, sales have been good and his business is growing thanks to the quality of his products and the good service he provides. Kurbonboy now requests a loan of 5200 Somoni which he will use to buy more clothes to meet his customers’ demand.  He is very thankful to you for helping him improve his business and therefore the quality of life for his family.

loans.use: To buy new summer clothing for selling.

loans.name: Rano

texts.en:
Rano D. is the divorced mother of two children. She is a private entrepreneur who works in the central city market selling women’s shoes. She offers a large variety of shoes at reasonable prices. Rano has been in business for 10 years. She has benefited a lot from 4 years of partnering with IMON International, Tajikistan. Lending services have helped her buy a new vending facility in a different part of the city, reach sustainability in her business, and have given her confidence for the future. Rano requests a loan of 5000 Somoni to re-stock her inventory and purchase shoes wholesale for the summer season. She believes that the sphere of market trade where she works is a promising niche and will continue to grow and develop in the future.

loans.use: To buy summer stock for her shoe store.

loans.name: Temur

texts.en:
Temur K. is 41 years old and married with three children. Together with his wife, Temur sells fabric for making the national dresses. Their store is located in the central local market. Temur has been in this business already for 18 years. In order to offer a wide range of goods for any taste and any wallet, Temur travels almost every month to the neighboring town to purchase the new goods. During his business absence Temur’s wife helps him in the market with selling. Temur has managed to increase his clientele but he is not able to fully meet the demand, therefore he requests a loan of 6000 Somoni so he can increase his stock. He hopes to earn more income so he can provide his children with a good education and with the best future. 

More about Tajikistan and IMON International:
Tajikistan is known for its rich history, which includes a key post along the Silk Road and the end of Alexander the Great's rule. loans.use: To buy more fabric for his shop.

loans.name: Anonymous

texts.en:
This Kiva borrower is a 40-year-old married woman from Lebanon. She has 3 children and two are still attending school. She has run a tailoring business from her home since 1984 when she decided to start a home business to support her husband with the family expenses. She works at the request of clients, making different designs of clothes, robes, shirts, pants, etc. in addition to clothing repair. She also does embroidery work. She is requesting a $1000 loan from Kiva partner Ameen s.a.l. to purchase additional textiles and a new sewing machine. She specifically notes that she will be able to deliver her services faster because of the new machine. In the future, she would like to expand her client base and she hopes to open a small tailoring factory.
 
Note: Based on the political and social challenges of Lebanon, personally identifiable attributes of this entrepreneur have been altered to protect him or her (i.e., blacking out portions of the entrepreneur in his/her picture, not indicating his/her name and location, etc.) Ameen s.a.l. appreciates Kiva lenders' understanding of these challenges and encourages lenders to continue their support for Lebanon's borrowers.

About Ameen:
Ameen s.a.l. has been a major player in the Lebanese Microfinance sector since 1999. Originally, a micro-credit program created by CHF International, Ameen evolved to become Ameen s.a.l. in 2003, a Lebanese services company. In 2007, Ameen s.a.l. registered with the Central Bank of Lebanon to become the first Lebanese financial institution specialized in Microfinance.

At Ameen s.a.l. we pledge to provide financial services to the largest number of micro and small entrepreneurs and to the working poor, to help them develop their businesses and improve their incomes.

Ameen has been able to use its interest-free loans Kiva to offer lower-interest loans with faster disbursement for their micro-loan borrowers. Since its inception, Ameen has provided high-quality financial services to over 41,000 borrowers and disbursed over 81,000 loans totaling $115 million. To learn more about Ameen, please visit http://partners.kiva.org/partners/115

loans.use: To buy more textiles and a new sewing machine.

loans.name: Dilorom

texts.en:
For the last ten years, Dilorom has dedicated herself to selling clothing in the market. She began by selling small quantities but through the years she has gone on to acquire greater quantities for sale. Dilorom began her business due to the needs of her family; her husband’s income did not suffice to cover the household expenses. As the years went by, her child was born, and her responsibility blossomed, since it was necessary to work harder to maintain her humble home. Currently Dilorom requests $1500 USD in order to re-stock her clothing inventory. She counts on your help and thanks all of you for your support.  

More about Tajikistan and IMON International

Tajikistan is known for its rich history, which includes being a key post along the Silk Road at the end of Alexander the Great's rule. It has also produced great thinkers, philosophers, scientists and poets, including Rudaki, Avicenna, Ferdowsi, Omar Khayyam, Jomi, and Rumi. The country is home to communities that still speak the ancient Sogdian language, epic mountain passes, and a civilization that dates back to the 4th millennium BC. And, even today, it is a complex mixture of the Islamic faith, Soviet culture, New West culture and Central Asian traditions.

But Tajikistan is also the poorest of the former Soviet republics. The civil war, which ignited soon after its independence from the U.S.S.R., further damaged the already weak economy. In addition, 93% of the country is mountainous and only 7% of the land is arable. These conditions have resulted in high levels of unemployment and have forced hundreds of thousands to seek work in other countries, mainly Russia. While the people of Tajikistan are working to improve its agricultural production and manufacturing sector, nearly two-thirds of the population still live in abject poverty.

IMON's History

Since December 2007, IMON International has worked closely with Kiva and Kiva lenders to ensure that poor and low income clients represent a viable business proposition. Funds raised through Kiva have already been distributed to thousands of IMON International's clients and will continue to provide thousands more with permanent access to the varied financial services they need. To learn more about IMON International's work, please visit: www.imon.tj

loans.use: Purchasing clothing to sell.

loans.name: Makongo Kk Group

texts.en:
Janeth D., aged 35, is married with two sons, 14 and 10.  She has been selling vitenge (fabrics) for 5 years.  She works from 9 am to 1 pm and she is able to make a monthly profit of about $33. This will be Janeth’s fourth loan from Tujijenge Tanzania. She used the previous loans to buy ulezi (brown wheat) to make  porridge and started selling vitenge.  She sells from door to door and is really doing fine and has managed to pay back the loans successfully.  She hopes for a new loan to buy vitenge and bed sheets. Janeth’s dream is to buy a car and transport her products to more customers

Janeth will share this loan with her loan group, Makongo KK, which totals 16 members.  The members of the group will hold each other accountable in paying back the loan. In the picture Janeth is  wearing a kitenge in the front row.

loans.use: To buy more fabrics and bedsheets to sell

loans.name: Akwata Empola Gambwa Womens Group 2-Mityana

texts.en: B. Silvester, 42, has subsisted on earnings from his seven-year-old retail shop to care for his family’s welfare. The business, which brings in 250,000 shillings per month, has enabled this married father of six to make ends meet. It’s with savings from his erstwhile farming business that Silvester began his retail business. His customers vary from the very poor to middle-class people around Gambwa-Mityana. With this loan, this hard-working gentleman wants to purchase bags of sugar, salt, plastics, and maize flour in bulk to resell at retail.

loans.use: The purchase in bulk of  items such as maize flour, bags of sugar, plastics, to resell at retail

loans.name: Uguloy

texts.en:
Uguloy lives in the city of Dushanbe with her 3 children. She has had a retail business for about two years and is in the process of expanding it. Uguloy sells a variety of clothing for women in local market. By offering a range of clothing items, she provides a convenient stop for her customers who often will buy more than just one item from her.

Uguloy has requested a loan of 4000 Somoni to increase her working capital and help sustain her business. Purchasing inventory from wholesalers has required a substantial investment from Uguloy which is why she decided to obtain a loan. This loan will give her added flexibility and will help cover some of her growing expenses while she develops a larger business. Additional profits generated by her business will provide Uguloy with stable income and the ability to support her dear children financially.  

More about Tajikistan and IMON International

Tajikistan is known for its rich history, which includes a key post along the Silk Road and the end of Alexander the Great's rule.
