It has also produced great thinkers, philosophers, scientists and poets, including Rudaki, Avicenna, Ferdowsi, Omar Khayyam, Jomi, and Rumi. The country is home to communities that still speak the ancient Sogdian language, epic mountain passes, and a civilization that dates back to the 4th millennium BC. And, even today, it is a complex mixture of the Islamic faith, Soviet culture, New West culture and Central Asian traditions.

But Tajikistan is also the poorest of the former Soviet republics. The civil war, which ignited soon after its independence from the U.S.S.R., further damaged the already weak economy. In addition, 93% of the country is mountainous and only 7% of the land is arable. These conditions have resulted in high levels of unemployment and have forced hundreds of thousands to seek work in other countries, mainly Russia. While the people of Tajikistan are working to improve its agricultural production and manufacturing sector, nearly two-thirds of the population still live in abject poverty.

IMON's History

Since December 2007, IMON International has worked closely with Kiva and Kiva lenders to ensure that poor and low income clients represent a viable business proposition. Funds raised through Kiva have already been distributed to thousands of IMON International's clients and will continue to provide thousands more with permanent access to the varied financial services they need. To learn more about IMON International's work, please visit: www.imon.tj

loans.use: Purchasing of shoes to expand her inventory

loans.name: Benkadi 1 Group

texts.fr:
Le groupe Benkadi 1est composé de cinq femmes mariées majoritairement dans des grandes familles traditionnelles, qui ont un âge moyen de 39 ans et 4 enfants. Elles habitent le village de Korobougou dans la commune rurale de Sébougou dans la 4ème région de Ségou (4ème région administrative du Mali). 
Elles se sont connues à travers des liens de mariage, de parenté et de voisinage. 
Dans le but d’avoir des intrants agricoles disponibles pendant l’hivernage, elles ont fait recours à Soro Yiriwaso et sont à leur 1er  cycle de prêt de campagne. 
Les membres du groupe vont cultiver dans l’ensemble de l’arachide, du mil et du gombo.
Madame Korotoumou  B. compte utiliser son prêt pour acheter 3 sacs de complexe céréale, 20kg de semence d’arachide, recruter la main d’œuvre pour les activités de labour et de sarclage dans ses champs. 
Elle se ravitaille en intrants à la foire de Ségou. Les activités de labour des champs sont l’œuvre des hommes alors que le désherbage est effectué par l’association des femmes du village. 
Sur une superficie de 3 hectares, Madame Korotoumou  B. espère avoir, 8 sacs de mil, 18sacs d’arachide et une trentaine de tasse de gombo. Une partie de la récolte des céréales est auto consommée tandis que le reste est vendu. 
Le bénéfice obtenu est utilisé pour prendre en charge les petits besoins du foyer en condiments et soins de santé des enfants.
texts.en:
The Benkadi 1 group is made up of five married women, most of whom have large, traditional families, who are on average 39 years old and have 4 children. They live in the Korobougou village in the rural town of Sébougou in the 4th region of Ségou (4th administrative region of Mali). They know each other from their marriages, families, and neighbors. In the goal of having available farming resources during the winter, they have turned to Soro Yiriwaso and are on their first loan. The group members are going to grow peanuts, millet, and okra. Mrs. Korotoumou B. plans to use her loan to buy 3 bags of grain, 20kg of peanut seeds, and to hire labor to work and hoe in the fields. She obtains what she needs at the marketplace in Ségou. Field labor is done by men, while weeding is done by the women in the village. From a 3-acre area, Mrs. Korotoumou B. hopes to get 8 bags of millet, 18 bags of peanuts and about 30 cups of okra. A part of the crop of grains will be used, and the rest sold. The profits will be used to pay for small household needs and healthcare for the children.

Translated from French by Sherry W., Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy fertilizer, peanut seeds, and field labor

loans.name: Dilshod

texts.en:
The need to improve his income and provide education to his 4 dear children is the reason Dilshod is courteously requesting this loan. He is a very responsible and hardworking father who for many years has been dedicated to the business of buying and selling clothes. Dilshod has so far accessed loans from IMON International four times and has seen his business expand. With the income, he said he has been able to educate his children as it is the most important for Dilshod. 

Today he is requesting a loan of 2600 USD to expand the business so that he can generate more income. Dilshod is very grateful to everyone who is helping him to achieve his dreams with this loan.  

More about Tajikistan and IMON International

Tajikistan is known for its rich history, which includes a key post along the Silk Road and the end of Alexander the Great's rule. It has also produced great thinkers, philosophers, scientists and poets, including Rudaki, Avicenna, Ferdowsi, Omar Khayyam, Jomi, and Rumi. The country is home to communities that still speak the ancient Sogdian language, epic mountain passes, and a civilization that dates back to the 4th millennium BC. And, even today, it is a complex mixture of the Islamic faith, Soviet culture, New West culture and Central Asian traditions.

But Tajikistan is also the poorest of the former Soviet republics. The civil war, which ignited soon after its independence from the U.S.S.R., further damaged the already weak economy. In addition, 93% of the country is mountainous and only 7% of the land is arable. These conditions have resulted in high levels of unemployment and have forced hundreds of thousands to seek work in other countries, mainly Russia. While the people of Tajikistan are working to improve its agricultural production and manufacturing sector, nearly two-thirds of the population still live in abject poverty.

IMON's History

Since December 2007, IMON International has worked closely with Kiva and Kiva lenders to ensure that poor and low income clients represent a viable business proposition. Funds raised through Kiva have already been distributed to thousands of IMON International's clients and will continue to provide thousands more with permanent access to the varied financial services they need. To learn more about IMON International's work, please visit: www.imon.tj

loans.use: Purchasing new clothing to sell

loans.name: Ahmed

texts.en:
Ahmed K. is a 23-year-old businessman. He is single but has a longtime girlfriend whom he intends to marry very soon. He lives with his mother and some other relatives who are his dependents.

For the past five years, Ahmed has been trading in menswear to help him generate enough income to support his dependents. His business is located in the central market of Bo city. He makes a lot of sales because his business is located in the city center.

Ahmed has a very good loan repayment history. He needs a loan of Le 3,000,000 to buy more bales of menswear to sell. He intends to use the proceeds from this loan to provide livelihood for his family and to reinvest in his business.

loans.use: To buy more men's clothes to sell

loans.name: Benkadi  2 Group

texts.fr:
Benkadi 2 est regroupement de huit femmes mariées majoritairement dans des grandes familles traditionnelles, qui ont en moyenne 27 ans et 2 enfants. Elles habitent le village de Korobougou dans la commune rurale de Sébougou dans la 4ème région administrative du Mali, qu’est Ségou et se sont connues à travers des liens de mariage et de parenté. 
Dans le but d’augmenter leurs superficies de culture pendant l’hivernage, elles ont fait recours à Soro Yiriwaso et sont à leur 1er  cycle de prêt de campagne. Les membres du groupe vont cultiver dans l’ensemble de l’arachide, du mil et du sésame.
Madame Foufa  B. compte utiliser son prêt pour acheter, 30kg de semence d’arachide, 2 sacs de complexe céréale,  recruter la main d’œuvre pour les activités de labour et de sarclage dans ses champs. 
Elle se ravitaille en intrants à la foire de Ségou. Les activités de labour des champs sont l’œuvre des hommes alors que celles du désherbage sont effectuées par l’association des femmes du village. 
Sur une superficie de 3 hectares, elle compte récolter 5 sacs de mil, 18 sacs d’arachide et 2 sacs de sésame. Les céréales et une partie de l’arachide sont auto consommées tandis que le sésame et le reste d’arachide sont vendus. 
Le bénéfice obtenu est utilisé pour assurer les besoins du foyer, la scolarisation et les soins de santé des enfants.
texts.en:
"Benkadi 2" is a group of eight married women mostly in large traditional families. The women average 27 years of age and two children living in the village of Korobougou, in the rural community of Sébougou, in the 4th administrative region of the Republic of Mali which is Segou. They know one another through ties of marriage and kinship. With the goal of increasing their arable land during the winter, they turned to the micro-finance institution Soro Yiriwaso and are now on their first farm loan cycle. The group members over all are going to grow peanuts, millet, and sesame. Ms. Foufa B. intends to use her loan for buying 30 kg of peanut seeds and 2 sacks of cereals fertilizer and for recruiting manual labor for plowing and weeding in the fields. She restocks her supplies at the Segou fair. Plowing the fields is men's work, while weeding is done by the women's association of the village. From three hectares of land, she plans on harvesting 5 sacks of millet, 18 sacks of peanuts, and 2 sacks of sesame. The grains and a portion of the peanuts are consumed at home, while the sesame and the remainder of the peanuts are sold. The profits obtained will be used to cover household needs, schooling, and health care for the children.

Translated from French by Dan Kuey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buying fertilizer (for grains) and peanut seeds and using manual labor for plowing and weeding.

loans.name: Galina

texts.en:
Galina is a market entrepreneur from Pavlograd. She is  divorced with a 19-year-old daughter. Galina sells women's clothing in the central marketplace of her home town. She offers a nice clothing selection of various sizes for different age groups. Galina launched her venture 15 years ago. Experience working in the trade and professionalism have helped her increase her inventory up to 60,000 Grivnyas today. Her monthly net profit ranges from 5,000 to 7,000 Grivnyas.   

Galina is seeking a loan of 9,000 Grivnyas to purchase seasonal clothing for fall and winter. Her business is the only source of income in the family: Galina's daughter is a college student and lives with her at the moment. Galina has an optimistic view of life. She never gives up and presses on even when faced with hardships. One of her plans is to generate additional profit and remodel her apartment which is a costly undertaking in Ukraine.

loans.use: to increase her turnover

loans.name: Irina

texts.en:
Irina is single. She lives in Zaporozhye and runs her retail business in one of the city markets. Irina sells women's footwear and sock liners, as well as shorts and shirts for men. She is the only entrepreneur in the marketplace who has such big vending kiosks. Irina started her enterprise 3 years ago. Currently, she has about 20,000 Grivnyas invested in inventory.  

Irina is requesting a loan of 5,400 Grivnyas to purchase seasonal footwear and re-stock her merchandise before fall. She is also hoping to diversify men's clothing merchandise in her second location. She is seeking to further develop her business. Irina is very goal-oriented which has been instrumental in her business achievements.

loans.use: To purchase seasonal footwear.

loans.name: Sergey

texts.en:
Sergey is married with two grown children. He is a businessman from Novomoskovsk. Sergey sells bags, backpacks, suitcases, etc. He also offers leather accessories repair services. His wife is a KIVA borrower, too. Currently, Sergey has 80,000 Grivnyas in inventory. His income amounts to 15,000 Grivnyas a month. 

Sergey is seeking a 12,000 Grivnya loan to purchase merchandise for his new store location. Sergey started his business as a small market vendor 2 years ago. Recently, he switched his sales location from the marketplace to a rented facility in a local mall called "City" in downtown Novomoskovsk. The floor space is about  861 square feet. Sergey works hard to help his family. His 2 year old grandson has a serious blood disorder and Sergey tries to make enough money to supply him with the necessary medication.

loans.use: To purchase merchandise for his new store.

loans.name: Benkadi 3 Group

texts.fr:
Le groupe Benkadi 3 est composé de dix femmes, toutes mariées dans des grandes familles traditionnelles. Elles ont un âge moyen de 34 ans et 3 enfants par femme. Elles habitent le village de Korobougou dans la commune rurale de Sébougou  dans la 4ème région administrative du Mali, qu’est Ségou. 
Elles se sont connues à travers des liens de mariage, de parenté et de leurs activités. Dans le but d’augmenter leurs superficies de culture pendant l’hivernage, elles ont fait recours à Soro Yiriwaso et sont à leur 1er cycle de prêt de campagne. Les membres du groupe vont cultiver essentiellement de l’arachide, du mil et du gombo.
Madame Nana B. compte utiliser son prêt pour acheter, 3 sacs de complexe céréale, 25 kg de semence d’arachide, recruter la main d’œuvre pour les activités de labour et de sarclage dans ses champs. 
Elle se ravitaille en intrants à la foire de Ségou. Les activités de labour des champs sont l’œuvre des hommes alors que le désherbage est effectué par l’association des femmes du village. 
Sur sa superficie de 2,9 hectares, Madame Nana  B. compte réaliser 6 sacs de mil, 20 sacs d’arachide et une vingtaine de tasse de gombo. Une partie de la récolte des céréales est auto consommée tandis que le reste est vendu. 
Le bénéfice obtenu est utilisé pour prendre en charge la scolarisation des enfants et les petits besoins du foyer.
texts.en:
The group Benkadi 3 is made up of ten women, all married with large traditional families. The women are 34 years old on average and an average of 3 children per woman. They live in the village of Korobougou in the rural community of Sébougou in the 4th administrative region of Mali, which is Ségou. They know one another through marital, parentage and business ties. With the goal of increasing the extent of their crop during the winter, they appealed to Soro Yiriwaso and are on their first farm loan. The group members will mainly cultivate peanuts, millet and gumbo. Mrs. Nana B. expects to use her loan to buy 3 bags of complex grains, 25 kg of peanut seeds, and to recruit a labor force for hard labor activities and hoeing in the fields. She obtains her supplies at the fair in Ségou. The business of laboring in the fields is men's work, while the weeding is done by the association of women in the village. In an area of 2.9 hectares, Mrs. Nana B. expects to get 6 bags of millet, 20 bags of peanuts and 20 cups of gumbo. A part of the grain harvest is consumed by herself, while the rest is sold. The profit obtained will be used to provide for the schooling of her children and the small needs of the household.

Translated from French by Martha Schmitz, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy fertilizer (complex grains), peanut seeds, and to use a labor force for laboring and hoeing.

loans.name: Fatoumata

texts.fr:
Madame  Fatoumata M. est âgée de 46 ans, veuve et mère  de 7 enfants.  Elle  vit  dans une grande famille traditionnelle au  quartier Darsalam de Ségou (quatrième région administrative de la république du Mali).
N’ayant pas fréquenté l’école pour des raisons sociales,  elle commença très tôt à faire le petit commerce auprès de sa maman qui vendait des condiments. Après plusieurs années d’apprentissage, elle a vite maîtrisé les rouges du commerce. Elle a appris la teinture lors de son exode à Ségou avec une femme dont elle était sa domestique. Elle mène cette activité depuis 15 ans et jouit d’une grande expérience et notoriété. Sa force de vente est due non seulement à la qualité de la teinture mais également à celle du tissu.
Pour faire de la teinture, elle dilue différents produits de teintures modernes et traditionnels dans de l’eau chaude ensuite elle trempe les tissus blancs  dans cette eau pour leur donner la couleur désirée. Les tissus teintés sont étalés sur une corde pour séchage. Ensuite elle les amène chez le couturier. Les habits une fois cousus sont  blanchis et soigneusement emballés. 
Dans le dessein d’augmenter son fonds de commerce, afin de réaliser plus de bénéfice, elle a fait recours à Soro Yiriwaso. Elle est  à son 1er  prêt   qu’elle compte utiliser pour acheter, 2 pièces de bazins moins riches. Elle s’approvisionne sur place.
Madame  Fatoumata M.  vend au comptant et à crédit à une clientèle composée de femmes et d’hommes.
Avec ce prêt, elle envisage réaliser un bénéfice mensuel de 40 000FCFA. Ce bénéfice lui permettra de se prendre en charge (paiement des charges du loyer, nourritures et médicaments).
Son ambition est d’avoir plus de ressources pour bien mener son activité car elle a de l’expérience et les clients ne manquent pas.
texts.en:
Mrs. Fatoumata M., 46, is a widowed mother of seven children. She lives in a big traditional family in the Darsalam neighborhood of Ségou (fourth administrative region of the Republic of Mali.) Not having attended school for socio-economic reasons, she began at a young age to do petty trading together with her mother who sold condiments. After several years' apprenticeship, she was well versed in that commercial activity. She learned dyeing during her stay in Ségou from a lady for whom she was working as a maid. She has been working in this trade for 15 years and has a lot of experience and is well-known. Her strength in sales is due not only to the quality of her dyeing but also of her cloth. To do her dyeing, she dilutes the various products used for modern and traditional cloth dyeing in hot water. Then she soaks the white fabrics in this liquid to give them the desired color. Then the dyed cloth is hung out on a line to dry. After that she brings them to the seamstress and once the clothes are sewn, they are washed and ironed and carefully wrapped. Wishing to grow her working capital so as to make more profit, she came to Soro Yiriwaso. She is on her first loan which she intends to use to buy two "less rich" lengths of "bazin" (damask). She buys the cloth where she works. Mrs. Fatoumata M. sells for cash and credit to a clientele composed of women and men. With this loan she hopes to make a monthly profit of 40,000 F CFA. This profit will allow her to support herself (paying rent, food, and for medicines.) Her ambition is to have more resources to enable her to do well in her business since she has plenty of experience and clients.

Translated from French by Teresa Kramer, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: buying the necessary supplies to do dyeing

loans.name: Obama Group

texts.en:
Saraya Nasoro, age 42, is married with three children aged 25, 20 and 14.  She has owned and operated a bar and guesthouse since 1984. She works from 6 am to midnight and she is able to earn a monthly profit of about $200.

This will be Saraya’s 5th loan from Tujijenge Tanzania. She used the previous loan to make improvements to her guesthouse, including putting televisions in each of the 10 rooms. She also used the loan to purchase supplies for her bar. She has successfully paid back the loans. She hopes for a new loan to expand her business to sell water and beer wholesale. Saraya dreams of building a new guesthouse.  

Saraya  will share this loan with her loan group Obama, which totals 15 members. The members of the group hold each other accountable in paying back the loan. 

In the picture, Saraya is in a black dress 1st on the left.

loans.use: To expand her business to sell water and beer wholesale.

loans.name: Anonymous

texts.en:
The Kiva borrower is a 26 year old single man from Lebanon. He lives with his family and 6 siblings. He is a relatively new business owner - he started working as a flooring worker almost three years ago.  His story illustrates the day-to-day challenges many people are facing in trying to help their families with their business income. Despite his situation, he feels positive about his business potential for the coming year because during those three years, he has been able to build a good business reputation. He is requesting to borrow $1000 from Kiva partner Ameen s.a.l. to buy tools for a project renovating a small building. And he will also purchase a small car to facilitate his transportation to the projects he works on. In the future, he looks forward to taking on bigger projects in his community. 
 
Note: Based on the political and social challenges of Lebanon, personally identifiable attributes of this entrepreneur have been altered to protect him or her (i.e., blacking out portions of the entrepreneur in his/her picture, not indicating his/her name and location, etc.). Ameen s.a.l. appreciates Kiva lenders' understanding of these challenges and encourages lenders to continue their support for Lebanon's borrowers.

About Ameen:
Ameen s.a.l. has been a major player in the Lebanese Microfinance sector since 1999. Originally, a micro-credit program created by CHF International, Ameen evolved to become Ameen s.a.l. in 2003, a Lebanese services company. In 2007, Ameen s.a.l. registered with the Central Bank of Lebanon to become the first Lebanese financial institution specialized in Microfinance.

At Ameen s.a.l. we pledge to provide financial services to the largest number of micro and small entrepreneurs and to the working poor, to help them develop their businesses and improve their incomes.

Ameen has been able to use its interest-free loans Kiva to offer lower-interest loans with faster disbursement for their micro-loan borrowers. Since its inception, Ameen has provided high-quality financial services to over 41,000 borrowers and disbursed over 81,000 loans totaling $115 million. To learn more about Ameen, please visit http://partners.kiva.org/partners/115

loans.use: To buy tools + purchase a small car.

loans.name: Elizabeth

texts.es:
La señora Elizabeth vive en casa de su hermano en  la ciudad de La Paz, esta soltera trabaja como transcriptora en un periódico de circulación nacional, es cliente de Impro con 5 créditos; esta es la  primera vez que solicita financiamiento a través  de Kiva, el crédito que solicita es para continuar sus estudios de contabilidad y de esta manera ascender en su trabajo y poder mejorar sus ingresos.

Por el carácter social puede acceder a un nuevo crédito.
texts.en:
Señora Elizabeth lives with her brother in the city of La Paz. She is single and works as a transcriptionist for a nationally circulated newspaper. As a client of Impro she has had 5 loans. This is her first time requesting a loan from Kiva. She will use the loan to continue her studies in accounting so that she can get a promotion and improve her income. Due to her social character, she qualifies for a new loan.

Translated from Spanish by Ann Achilli, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To pay registration fees and to buy school supplies to continue her studies in accounting

loans.name: Celia

texts.es:
La señora Celia vive en casa propia en la zona de san Martín de la ciudad de La Paz, esta casada tiene tres hijos en edad escolar de 10,7 y 3 años , el esposo trabaja como chofer asalariado y ella vende almuerzos para generar sus ingresos y poder ayudar a su familia, primera ves que saca crédito en Impro y es Kiva también por primera vez.
El crédito lo destinará a la compra de arroz, papa, fideo y otros insumos para su  negocio de venta de comida.
Por el carácter social puede acceder a un crédito.
texts.en:
Celia lives in her own house in the San Martín area of the city of La Paz. She is married and has three school age children; ten, seven, and three years old. Her husband works as a salaried drive. She sells lunches to generate income and to be able to help her family. This is her first loan with Impro, and it is also her first with Kiva. She will use the loan to buy rice, potatoes, noodles, and other supplies for her business of selling food. Her character and reputation qualify her for a loan.

Translated from Spanish by Ginny Kalish, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buy supplies for her business of selling food

loans.name: Bendiya 1 Group

texts.fr:
Les dix membres du groupe BENDIYA 1 sont des femmes mariées  ayant une moyenne d’âge de 41ans, 5  enfants et vivant la plupart dans des  familles polygames à MOSSIBOUGOU, un des villages de la commune de LOULOUNI dans la sous préfecture  de LOULOUNI, 3ème région administrative du Mali. 
Elles collaborent avec l’institution de microfinance Soro Yiriwaso afin de mener à bien leurs activités agricoles pendant l’hivernage. 
Elles sont à leur deuxième prêt avec l’institution, le prêt passé a été bien remboursé.
Les spéculations cultivées sont : la patate, le niébé et le pois sucré avec KADIATOU S..
Avec son prêt, elle compte acheter des intrants et les petits matériels pour entretenir : 1,5 hectare. 
La production est vendue au niveau du village, au marché du village de DALLEN et au marché de LOULOUNI après la récolte à une clientèle composée d’hommes et de femmes. 
Elle compte réaliser un bénéfice moyen de 62.500FCFA par campagne.
Ce bénéfice lui permettra de payer son prêt et aussi d’aider son mari dans les dépenses quotidiennes.
Elle souhaite entretenir  cette collaboration avec Soro Yiriwaso afin d’ exploiter un espace cultural encore plus grand pour mieux en tirer plus de gains.
NB: Nawa C.  était partie accompagner Aminata C. pour son accouchement au centre de santé, raison de leur absence sur la photo de groupe.
texts.en:
The Bendiya 1 group consists of ,married women with an average age of 41 and with five children. Mostly, they live in polygamous families in Mossibougou, a village in the commune of Loulouni in the subprefecture of Loulouni (Mali's Third Administrative Region). They work with Soro Yiriwaso, a microfinance institution, to be able to have more control over their farming activtyy during the rains. This is their second loan. The first was repaid properly. Kadiatou S.'s crops are potatoes, black-eyed peas, and snow peas. With her loan she plans to buy fertilizer and hand tools for cultivating 1.5 hectares, and hopes to make a profit of 62,500 CFA for the season so she can pay back her loan and help her husband out with family expenses. She would like to continue working with Soro Yiriwaso and cultivate more land so she can increase her income. Note: Nawa Coilibaly was with Aminata C. while Aminata was giving birth, so neither of them is in the group photo.

Translated from French by Michael Briggs, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buy fertilizer and hand tools

loans.name: Ricardo

texts.es:
El señor Ricardo vive en anticretico en la zona de San Martín de la ciudad de La Paz esta a casado tiene tres hijos, de los cuales dos ya son casados y una en edad escolar con la que viven. Ricardo tiene un taxi con el cual trabaja todos los días en transporte libre generando así sus ingresos para subsistir; el crédito que solicita es para comprar llantas y mantener su herramienta de trabajo en buenas condiciones. Ya van 8 créditos que tiene con impro, fue cliente de Kiva 3 veces.

Por el carácter social puede acceder a un nuevo crédito.
texts.en:
Ricardo lives in “anticretico” (a special type of rental arrangement in Bolivia) in the San Martín area of La Paz. He is married and has three children. Two of them are married, and one is school age and lives with them. Ricardo has a taxi, and he is self-employed. He works with his taxi everyday generating income to survive. The loan that he is requesting is to buy tires and to keep his working tool in good condition. He has had eight loans with Impro, and he has been a Kiva borrower three times. His character and reputation qualify him for a loan.

Translated from Spanish by Ginny Kalish, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buy tires and maintenance on his taxi

loans.name: Rutendere Women's, Kihihi Group

texts.en:
Maurice T. operates a 4 year old garment sales business in Butogota trading centre, while selling clothes in monthly and weekly markets in the area, earning 360,000 Ugandan shillings on a monthly basis. This has inspired her more in her business.

Having noticed the prevailing market in the area from local occupants and travelers, she started a clothes business. It is for this reason that she wants to get this loan to improve her financial prospects in terms of restocking her business with attractive materials and more bales of clothes.
 
By her own account, the future of her business is promising and this will see her earn more revenue as she manages to maintain her customers by doing timely shopping for them. With the loan she wants to purchase more garments to give her business a new lease on life, which will improve her sales revenue and enable her to take care of her family.

Maurice belongs to a group of members who insure and hold each other accountable in paying back the loan.

loans.use: To buy more bales of clothes for resale.

loans.name: Samaria

texts.en: Samaria P. is currently in the business of selling charcoal at home, and is requesting a loan to stock more bags of charcoal to sell. Samaria is 31 years old and is married to a husband who is a peasant. She has 2 children and her children go to school. With the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to buy a motor bike for hire.

loans.use: To stock more bags of charcoal to sell.

loans.name: Julieta

texts.es:
La señora Julieta vive en casa propia en la zona  Ernesto Torrez de la ciudad de La Paz, esta casada tiene dos hijos en edad escolar, el esposo trabaja con su micro en transporte publico, ella vende ropa americana a medio uso y ropa nueva para ayudar en el hogar; ya obtuvo varios créditos en Impro (8) y también fue cliente de Kiva en dos oportunidades y está muy satisfecha. El crédito será utilizado para la compra de poleras y ropa de vestir al por mayor.

Por el carácter social puede acceder a un nuevo crédito.
texts.en:
Julieta lives in her own house in the Ernesto Torrez area of the city of La Paz. She is married and has two school age children. Her husband works with his small bus in public transportation. She sells used American clothes and new clothes to help at home. She has had several loans with Impro (8), and she was a Kiva borrower twice. She is very pleased with the loans. She will use the loan to buy skirts and other garments wholesale. Her character and reputation qualify her for a new loan.

Translated from Spanish by Ginny Kalish, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buy skirts and other garments for her business of selling clothing

loans.name: Siranush

texts.en: Siranush A. is 25 years old, and lives with her mother. To support herself and her mother from a young age, Siranush opened a clothing business which she has run since 2002. She rents a spot in a trading market place, from where she sells women’s clothing. Siranush regularly imports clothing to meet her clientele’s demand. It is more expedient for her to travel to the neighboring country to make the purchase personally. This loan will cover the purchase of clothing and customs fees.

loans.use: To cover the purchase of clothing and customs fees.

loans.name: Nyarutojo Tukwatanise, Kihihi Group

texts.en:
Through hustling and toiling, one hard working Ellias T., aged 40, managed to invest in the timber sector for over 5 years now, after exploring the potential from his own planted trees. He was driven into this business by the fact there is a lot demand in the prevailing market from Nyarutojo Trading centre where he does his business. He does this with the support of his spouse, along with their milk sales business, and they earn a good profit in Ugandan shillings.

With a lot of work requiring timber as a raw material, including furniture workshops, building and construction, Ellias hopes to expand his business by getting this loan and opening up supply stores and buying more timber for sale. This will enable him to earn more revenue and be able to maintain a self-sustaining life and meet his lifelong dream of educating his children.

loans.use: To purchase more timber for resale.

loans.name: Lona

texts.en: Lona J. is currently in the business of selling tomatoes and dried fish at the market and is requesting a loan to stock onions and Irish potatoes to sell. Lona is 54 years old and is married to a husband who is a head teacher. She has 4 children and her children go to school. With the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to build a house for rent.

loans.use: To stock onions and Irish potatoes to sell.

loans.name: Gisela

texts.es:
Gisela es soltera, vive en casa de sus padres en la zona de san Martín de la ciudad de la Paz, no tiene hijos, es propietaria de un micro que le rinde ingresos diarios para su subsistencia, fue cliente de Kiva en dos oportunidades, y de  Impro con 4 créditos, los cuales pago puntualmente. El crédito será utilizado para la compra de llantas para su micro de transporte de pasajeros.

Por el carácter social puede acceder a un nuevo crédito.
texts.en:
Gisela is single and lives in her parents' house in the San Martín zone of the city of La Paz. She has no children and is the proprietor of a micro-enterprise that renders income daily for her subsistence. Gisela has been a client of Kiva on 2 previous occasions, and of Impro for 4 loans, all of which were repaid punctually. This loan will be utilized to buy tires for her micro-van that transports passengers. Given her social character, she is eligible for a new loan.

Translated from Spanish by Harold Sims, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: BUYING TIRES FOR HER MICRO-VAN THAT TRANSPORTS PASSENGERS

loans.name: Hawa

texts.en: Hawa A. is currently in the business of selling various items in her retail shop and is requesting a loan to stock more boxes of soap, bags of sugar, and salt to sell. Hawa is 41 years old and is married to a husband who is a secretary. She has 5 children and her children go to school. With the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to extend the floor of her restaurant.

loans.use: To stock more boxes of soap, bags of sugar, and salt to sell.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To buy more cartons of various foodstuffs to sell

loans.name: German

texts.es:
German vive en alquiler con su esposa e hijos en la zona de San Martín de la ciudad de La Paz, esta casado tiene dos hijos que están en edad escolar; hace un año atrás se compro un auto el cual trabaja el mismo como taxi  todos los días, con los ingresos que obtiene mantiene a su familia, la esposa vende cds y algunas otras cosas para ayudar a su hogar; el crédito que saco anteriormente fue para reparar su movilidad, y fue parte de Kiva en dos créditos, y de Impro con 8 créditos. German esta satisfecho con los créditos obtenidos y desea solicitar uno para comprar más productos como ser dc, mp3 musicales, películas, etc., para continuar el negocio de su esposa. 

Por su antecedente histórico califica para obtener un nuevo crédito, pues se lo considera buen cliente.
texts.en:
Germán lives in a rental home with his wife and children in the San Martín zone of the city of La Paz. He is married and has 2 children who are of school age. A year ago, he bought an auto which he drives as a taxi every day. With this income, Germán maintains his family. His wife sells CDs and some other things to aid with household expenses. His previous loans were used to repair his car. Two of these were with Kiva and 8 were with Impro. Germán is pleased with the loans he obtained and now, he wishes to solicit another to buy more products, such as CDs, MP3 musicals, films, etc., to help his wife continue her business. Given his historical antecedents, Germán qualifies to obtain a new loan, since he is considered a good client.

Translated from Spanish by Harold Sims, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: BUYING CDs, MP3 MUSICALS, AND FILMS TO SELL

loans.name: Agnes

texts.en: Agnes K. is currently in the business of selling drugs in a medical clinic and is requesting a loan to stock more drugs to sell. Agnes is 40 years old and is married to a husband who is a builder. She has 4 children and her children go to school. With the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to extend her medical clinic to wards.

loans.use: To stock more drugs to sell.

loans.name: Ginelba

texts.es:
La señora Ginelba vive en zona de San Martin de la ciudad de la Paz, con sus esposo y sus dos niños que aun son pequeños, vive en casa de su madre y el esposo trabaja como chofer de transporte libre  pero sus ingresos son pocos por lo tanto ella vende Cds, para ayudar en su hogar; ya fue cliente de Impro y el primer préstamo se le concedió para capital; actualmente el negocio marcha muy bien y mejoro sus ingresos.
El préstamo que solicita será para ampliar su negocio y comprar productos de belleza YAMBAL y también más CDs para su venta al por menor.

Por el carácter social puede acceder a un nuevo crédito.
texts.en:
Señora Ginelba lives in the San Martin area in the city of La Paz with her husband and their two small children. She lives with her mother and her husband works as a self employed taxi driver, but his wages are low. For this reason she sells CDs to help with the household expenses. She is a client of Impro and the first loan she was granted provided her with capital. Currently, her business is doing very well and her income has increased. She is requesting a loan to expand her retail business and buy Yanbal beauty products and also, more CDs to sell. Due to her social character, she qualifies for a new loan.

Translated from Spanish by Ann Achilli, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To purchase CDs and Yanbal beauty products to sell retail

loans.name: Lily

texts.en: Lily M. is currently in the business of selling maize flour and beans at the market and is requesting a loan to stock bags of rice and pulses (a type of grain) to sell. Lily is 30 years old and is married to a husband who is an electrician. She has 2 children and her children go to school. With the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to build a store for her goods to be saved from the rains.

loans.use: To stock bags of rice and pulses to sell.

loans.name: Braulio

texts.es:
Braulio vive en la zona central de la ciudad de La Paz.
El señor es viudo, y tiene tres hijos que son independientes y casados.
Braulio tiene un vehiculo que trabaja como taxi, y contrata una persona para que pueda manejar su vehiculo.
Es la primera vez que solicita un crédito en impro, con este crédito el señor podrá hacer arreglar su vehiculo y poner en buenas condiciones para que, genere mejores ingresos.
texts.en:
Braulio lives in the central area of La Paz. He is a widower, and he has three children who are independent and married. Braulio has a vehicle, which is used as a taxi. He hires someone to drive the vehicle. This is the first time he has requested a loan from Impro. He will use the loan to fix his vehicle and get it into good condition. He will do this to generate greater income.

Translated from Spanish by Ginny Kalish, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Maintenance on his taxi

loans.name: Elizabeth

texts.en: Elizabeth D. is currently in the business of selling both dried and fresh fish at the market and is requesting a loan to stock Irish potatoes and tomatoes to sell. Elizabeth is 30 years old and is married to a husband who is a teacher. She has 2 children and her children go to school. With the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to build a house for rent.

loans.use: To stock Irish potatoes and tomatoes to sell.

loans.name: Jose Luis

texts.es:
José Luis vive en la zona de Bella Vista. de la ciudad de La Paz, 
Es soltero y no tiene hijos.
 José Luis es empleado en una empresa de embutidos, y quiere comenzar a vender diferentes artículos para el hogar ( calderas, termos, lámparas y otros), este será el objeto del crédito.
Es la primera vez que solicita un crédito en Impro. Con este crédito el señor podrá mejorar sus ingresos y su calidad de vida.
texts.en:
José Luis lives in the Bella Vista area of the city of La Paz. His is single, and he does not have children. José Luis works for a sausage company. He wants to start selling different items for the home (pots, thermos bottles, lamps, and other items). That is why he wants the loan. This is the first time that he has requested a loan from Impro. With this loan he will be able to improve his income and his quality of life.

Translated from Spanish by Ginny Kalish, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buy household items like pots, thermos bottles, lamps, and other items to sell later

loans.name: Aidarbek

texts.en:
Aidarbek K. was born in Nurmanbet village, where he still lives. He is 32 years old and has three sons who are seven, four and two. He was the youngest child in a large family, where all the children helped their parents in the household and they cultivated land and pastured cattle. After graduating from secondary school and serving in the Army, Aidarbek got married. His parents gave a milk cow to the couple, thereby making a distinctive contribution to the start of Aidarbek’s business.

Aidarbek is a hard worker and his strong efforts allowed him to broaden his business with three cows and two bulls. His wife milks the cows and sells about 20 liters of milk daily to the loyal customers. Also, Aidarbek cultivates a small plot of land with red beets and cabbage. Aidarbek plans to use this loan of 50,000 Kyrgyz Soms to buy one milk cow and sheep, because it’s a good way to find the means for subsistence of the five member family. 

Aidarbek believes strongly that his children will become educated in the future. And today, he makes every effort to reach this goal. 

Bai-Tushum and Partners uses Kiva funding to target the especially vulnerable population. Bai-Tushum and Partners is one of the leading Microfinance Institutions in Kyrgyzstan. As a reliable financial partner, Bai-Tushum contributes to the economic development of the Kyrgyz Republic through the delivery of microfinance services in rural and urban areas that lead to increased employment and meet the interests of its clients and investors.

loans.use: To purchase cattle.

loans.name: Jakeline

texts.es:
Jakeline vive en la zona de Escobar Uria de la ciudad de La Paz.
Esta casada y tiene tres hijos, de 7 años, 3 años y 3 meses.
La señora tiene un negocio de Internet y juegos en red en su domicilio desde hace tres años; su esposo trabaja como empleado en una fotocopiadora.
Es la tercera vez que solicita un crédito en Impro, y la segunda vez que requiere el apoyo de kiva, demostrando responsabilidad en el pago de sus cuotas. El crédito será utilizado para lacompra de una impresora Lasser a color y sus accesorios, para ofrecer servicios de impresión en su negocio.
texts.en:
Jakeline lives in Escobar Uria, a neighborhood of the town of La Paz. She is married and has three children: one is a 3 month-old baby, the other two are aged 7 and 3. She has been running and Internet café with video games services in her house for three years; her husband works in a photocopying shop. This is the third loan she is requesting to Impro, and the second time she is asking for support from Kiva: she has demonstrated being responsible with the repayments of her dues. The loan will be used to buy a laser color printer and its spare parts, in order to add a printing service to her activity.

Translated from Spanish by Emanuela Villa, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy a laser color printer

loans.name: Luis Manuel

texts.es: Luis Manuel  tiene una pulpería de venta tanto de alimentos y productos de uso diario en su comunidad. Tiene dos hijos menores de edad a su cargo, por lo que cada día lucha por proporcionarle los servicios básicos. Su negocio está ubicado en su casa de habitación, pues cuando inicio fue con cafetín en donde ofrecía café, jugos, pan, repostería, galletas y golosinas pero con el paso del tiempo logro obtener un buen capital y establecer su negocio en su vivienda. Este es su primer financiamiento destinado para la compra de golosinas, refrescos, pan, galletas y granos básicos.
texts.en:
Luis Manuel has a grocery store where he sells food items and daily use items in his community. He has two minor children under his care which motivate him to work daily to provide them with the basics. His store is located in his home because when he started out he had a small snack bar where he sold coffee, juices, bread, pastry, cookies and sweets. In time he acquired enough capital to set up his store in his home. This is his first loan and it will be used to buy sweets, beverages, bread, cookies and basic grains.

Translated from Spanish by Michael Bujazan, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy stock items for his store.

loans.name: Yawa

texts.en: Yawa B. currently sells charcoal at her home and is requesting a loan in order to stock more bags of charcoal to sell.  She is 41 years old and married a watchman. She has 4 children who all go to school. With the extra profits from her loans, she hopes to be able to build a shop.

loans.use: To stock more bags of charcoal to sell.

loans.name: Rugando Farmers & Traders B, Kihihi Group

texts.en:
As they say, determination is a key to success. T. Jovlet, a happily married mother of 5 children, ventured into tea growing in Nyamirambi, Kihihi, over 10 years ago. This was after realizing the readily available market in the area for a tea factory, that she developed an interest in growing and selling tea leaves alongside her banana plantation business. This enterprise has seen her earn 200,000 Ugandan shillings on a monthly basis, which has greatly had an impact on her standard of living.

Her main drawback is the land being infertile with low yields, therefore, with this loan she will buy fertilizer and manure and further expand the tea plantation through buying more seedlings and doing it on a large scale. This will improve her yields, sales, and enable Jovlet to take care of her family's needs.

loans.use: To buy fertilizer and seedlings for the tea plantation.

loans.name: James

texts.en:
James T. is a fifty-year-old teacher as well as a businessman. He is married to a teacher with five children: two are in primary school and the other three are in secondary school.

James established a bar business three years back when he noticed that he needed another source of income to support his family. His bar is located in Njai Town, Bo. His college teachers and other people in the Njai town community spend their leisure time in his bar, particularly in the evening.

James has a good loan repayment history. He needs a loan of 3,000,000 SLL so that he can fully stock his bar as he has more customers now, including his colleague teachers who love to spend more time at the bar.

James believe that the proceeds from this loan will help him provide livelihood for his family, educate his children and enable him to start to building a house for his family.

loans.use: To buy more drinks for his bar

loans.name: Julia

texts.es:
Julia vive en la zona de Achumani, de la ciudad de La Paz.
Esta separada de su esposo  y tiene un hijo de 18 años que esta en la Universidad.
Se dedica a la compra y venta de productos de belleza, hace 5 años.El crédito será utilizado en la compra de productos AVON y tambien ropa de mujer, para continuar son su negocio de venta al por menor.
Es la quinta vez que solicita un crédito en Impro, y la tercera vez que requiere el apoyo de Kiva, demostrando responsabilidad en el pago de sus cuotas.
texts.en:
Julia lives in the Achumani neighborhood of the town of La Paz. She is separated from husband and has a 18 year-old son attending University. She has been engaging in buying and selling beauty products for 5 years. The loan will be used to buy AVON products as well as women’s’ clothes to keep on with her retail activity. This is the firth time she has requested a loan to Impro, and the third time she has asked Kiva for support, proving herself to be responsible with the repayments of her dues.

Translated from Spanish by Emanuela Villa, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy beauty products and women’s’ clothes.

loans.name: Rugando Farmers & Traders A, Kihihi Group

texts.en:
In his mid 60’s, it’s hard to imagine that B. Jackson has been running an agriculture enterprise for over 30 years, and is still at his best proving to fellow business men that he can make it. Having been inspired and trained by his parents for quite some time, hard working Jackson got a vision to start up a banana plantation business alongside a coffee sales income enterprise. He gets 280,000 Ugandan shillings on a monthly basis from mobile buyers.

However, his main drawback is harvesting poor quantities, and therefore with this loan he will be able to purchase mulches and manure for his coffee and banana plantations. This will make it possible for him to earn more revenue and cater for his family of 6 children and wife at home, and to further go for his goal of expanding business and educating his 3 children who are still attending school.

loans.use: To buy manure and mulches for the plantations.

loans.name: Melida

texts.es:
Melida vive en la zona de Villa la Merced, de la ciudad de La Paz.
Esta separada de su esposo, tiene dos hijos, de 5 años y otro de 8 meses.
Ella es profesora y también vende productos de belleza hace dos años.
Es la tercera vez que solicita un crédito en Impro, y la segunda vez que requiere el apoyo de Kiva.
Con este crédito la señora podrá compra mas productos de belleza (cosméticos perfumes, pinturas y tintes) dándole las posibilidades de aumentar sus ingresos.
texts.en:
Melida lives in the Villa la Merced neighborhood in La Paz. She separated from her husband, and has two children ages 5 and 8 months. She is a teacher and has also been selling beauty products for the past two years. This is the third time she has requested a loan with Impro and the second time with Kiva's help. This loan will allow her to buy more beauty products (perfumes, makeup and hair color) giving her the chance to increase her income.

Translated from Spanish by Solson Scherman, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase beauty products to continue her reatail sales business

loans.name: Hercilia Patricia

texts.es: Doña Hercilia tienen 39 años de edad es originaria de San RAymundo su esposo esta en los Estados Uidos, tienen 4 hijos 3 viven con ella y 1 ya no, ella se dedica a la venta de carne de marrano y chicharrones en su casa ya hace 25 años, nos cuenta que le ha ido muy bien por eso quiere incrementar la venta, ahora quiere invertir una parte en la comra de marranos peruqeños y asi ella engordarlos para luego destazarlos, asi espra un poco mas de ganancia ya que los marranos grandes se los venden un poco caros y la otra parte quiere invertirlo en la compra de marranos ya grandes, ella espera lograr sus objetivos y aún mas.
texts.en:
Hercilia is 39 years old and comes from San Raymundo. Her husband is in the United States. They have 4 children, 3 of whom still live with her; one is already grown. Her work is selling pork meat and chicharrones [fried pork skin] from her home. She has done this work for 25 years now, and she says that it has gone very well for her. For that reason, she would like to increase her sales. She would now like to invest part of the loan in buying small pigs to fatten up and later butcher. In this way, she hopes to achieve a little more profit, since large pigs are rather expensive to buy. She would like to invest the other part of the loan funds in buying large pigs. She hopes to achieve her goals and even more.

Translated from Spanish by Patricia Linderman, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Investing in her business

loans.name: Nueva Union 6 & 7 Group

texts.en:
Josely is the coordinator of her group "Nueva Union 6 & 7" (New Union). Josely is excited to be taking her 5th loan. She plans to use this loan to invest in her business where she sells clothing and catalogue products (especially cosmetics). She also is a tailor and makes clothes and other stuff. She makes her home in a simple structure with her two children, being a young single mom. She will buy some products and clothes for her business and a sewing machine to sew different items for the home and people. She says that her most difficult challenge is to have a united family. She enjoys sewing and any time she is free, likes to create.

Josely is planning to have a medical check-up as soon as possible. She will use the profits from her business to buy school supplies and a computer. Her future with Esperanza means more loans to invest in her business, and she wants to work, grow and improve so she can bring in more income for her family.

This Esperanza associate’s story is representative of her group and of Esperanza's Haitian and Dominican clients (many of whom recently emigrated to the DR from Haiti) generally. Her group is located in a rural area in Samana, a city on the north coast of the Island, and like nearly all impoverished areas of the Dominican Republic, suffers from unreliable electricity and running water (none of which is potable).

loans.use: To buy clothing and catalogue products, and a sewing machine.

loans.name: Anonymous Group
loans.use: To buy more gallons of oil and more bags of charcoal.

loans.name: Cesar

texts.es:
Cesar es un padre de familia de 32 años de edad que vive junto a su esposa y un hijo en el distrito de Tambogrande, un distrito agrícola caracterizado principalmente por producir frutas las cuales son tratadas para ser exportadas, pertenece a la provincia de Piura y se encuentra ubicado en la región del mismo nombre, a mas de tres horas de la ciudad de Chiclayo, capital de la región Lambayeque.

Se dedica a labores asociadas a la agricultura desde su juventud, el cuenta con un terreno de cultivo donde suele sembrar mango y limón, cuando estas frutas ya están cosechadas, las ofrece en venta a las plantas procesadoras de la zona, las cuales preparan las frutas para ser exportadas al extranjero. Esta actividad es su principal fuente de ingresos, adicionalmente se dedica también a la crianza y venta de ganado vacuno y ovino.

Cesar desea comprar algunos fertilizantes para brindar mantenimiento a sus cultivos, de modo que pueda asegurarse una buena producción, para lograr su objetivo ha creído pertinente solicitar por primera vez a Edpyme Alternativa un crédito de 1000 nuevos soles que le ayuden a lograr su objetivo.

Cesar es un padre honrado y trabajador, su mayir anhelo es seguir trabajando para sacar a su familia adelante, en la zona donde vive sus vecinos y conocidos le tienen mucha estima y le consideran alguien de confianza.
texts.en:
Cesar is a 32-year-old father who lives with his wife and one child in the district of Tambogrande, an agricultural zone characterized by the production of fruit that is prepared for export. It belongs to Piura province and lies within the region of the same name, more than three hours from the city of Chiclayo, the capital of the Lambayeque region. Cesar has worked in agriculture since he was a boy. He has a farm where he usually plants mangoes and limes. When these fruits have been harvested, he offers them for sale to the processing plants in the area, which prepare the fruit to be exported abroad. This activity is his main source of income. He also works raising and selling cattle and sheep. Cesar wants to buy various types of fertilizer to provide maintenance to his crops, so that he can ensure a good level of production. To achieve this aim, he has decided to request a loan for the first time from Edpyme Alternativa in the amount of 1000 Peruvian new soles, which will help him reach his goal. Cesar is an honest and hard-working father. His greatest desire is to keep working so that he can help his family get ahead. In the area where he lives, his neighbors and others who know him hold him in high esteem and consider him someone they can trust.

Translated from Spanish by Patricia Linderman, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buying fertilizers to maintain his mango and lime crops

loans.name: Women Of Progress Group

texts.en:
Josephine T., who is holding the sign, is the leader of this group of five borrowers called Women Of Progress.

Josephine is 40 years old, married, and has seven children who range from 3 to 22 years old. She was not privileged to attend school due to poverty. She cares for one sibling. 

For 8 years, she has been selling fish (fresh and dried) in Redlight Market, on the outskirts of Monrovia, Liberia. She plans to use her 9,000 Liberian Dollars portion of this 45,000 Liberian Dollars group loan to buy more cartons of fish.

She describes herself as a hard-working woman. Her goal is to improve her business, and build a house.

In the photo that accompanies this profile, Malda Z. is inset at the lower left because she was absent during the interview.

loans.use: To buy more cartons of fish.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: Supplies for graphics printing business.

loans.name: La Superacion Ii, Grupo 5 Group

texts.en:
Eufrecia is the coordinator of her group La Superacion II, Grupo 5 (The Overcoming). She makes her home here in a simple structure with her husband and two children. She plans to continue enjoying decorating homes, which she likes a lot and learned years before; she also likes to sew fabrics for the home.

Eufrecia is excited to be taK. her third loan with Esperanza after having successfully repaid her previous loan and grown her business. She has had her business for over six years. She starting by buying flowers and maK. small bouquets, then sold them and reinvested. 

She plans to use this loan to invest in her business by buying an industrial sewing machine and some fabrics. She will use the profits to buy school supplies for her children.

"School vacation is almost over, and my children will start again soon," she said.

She also wants to buy some medicine, add telephone service and buy a computer. By saving, she is planning to move her business to a more accessible and bigger locale, where she can become sustainable and have employees. For her future, she hopes to build a house and have a car.
   
This Esperanza associate says she began with us because, "I have a business and interest rate(s) are good. I'm maK. friends and this is really important for me and my business."

Her  story is representative of her group and of Esperanza's Haitian and Dominican clients, many of whom recently emigrated to the DR from Haiti. Her group is located in Samana, a lush, rugged peninsula with a nascent tourism industry. This area, like nearly all impoverished areas of the Dominican Republic, suffers from unreliable running water (none of which is potable) and electricity.

loans.use: To buy an industrial sewing machine

loans.name: Bendiya 2 Group

texts.fr:
Les dix membres du groupe BENDIYA 2 sont des femmes mariées  qui ont une moyenne d’âge de 34ans, ont en moyenne 3  enfants et  vivent la plupart dans des  familles polygames à MOSSIBOUGOU un des villages de la commune de LOULOUNI dans la sous préfecture  de LOULOUNI, 3ème région administrative du Mali. 
Elles collaborent avec l’institution de microfinance Soro Yiriwaso afin de mener à bien leurs activités agricoles pendant l’hivernage. Elles sont à leur deuxième prêt avec l’institution, le prêt passé a été bien remboursé.
DIATOU C. qui est un des membre du groupe s’est spécialisée dans la culture du pois de terre.
Avec son prêt, elle compte acheter des intrants et les petits matériels pour entretenir : 2 hectares. 
Après la récolte la production est essentiellement vendue au marché de LOULOUNI à une clientèle composée d’hommes.. 
Elle compte réaliser un bénéfice moyen de 120 000 FCFA par campagne.
Son bénéfice lui permettra de payer son prêt et aussi à participer  dans certaines dépenses quotidiennes de la famille.
texts.en:
The ten members of the group BENDIYA 2 are married women with an average age of 34. They all have 3 children on average and most live in polygamous families in Moosibougou, one of the villages in the commune of Loulouni in the Sikasso Region of southern Mali. They collaborate with the Microfinance insitution Soro Yiriwaso in order to successfully carry out their agricultural activities during winter. This is their second loan with the institution, with the first being duly repaid. Diatou C., who is one of the members of the group, specialises in the cultivation of bambara groundnut. With her loan, she intends to buy agricultural products and equipment to cultivate 2 hectares. After the harvest, the produce is sold at the market of Louloni to male clientele. She hopes to make an average profit of 120 000 FCFA each season. Her profits will enable her to repay her loan and also to assist with the daily family expenses.

Translated from French by Kate Bennett, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Achat d’intrants et petits matériels agricoles.

loans.name: Akwata Empola Gambwa Womens Group 1- Mityana

texts.en: "Always try to derive by all means necessary good bargains out of even unfortunate business circumstances." That is the precept and philosophy that 30-year-old Harriet N. has applied in her retail business operations over the last five years in Gambwa-Mityana. This affable, evergreen and happy-go-lucky married mother of four buoyant school-going children has improved her profits with this modus operandi. She seized the opportunity to get established in this general store business after much persuasion from her husband. With an open mind, she started off even though she had no prior business experience. In a month, her profits add up to 200,000 Ugandan shillings. Harriet also ekes out side income from agricultural and rental businesses. With the assistance of this loan, she is looking at buying a plot of land.

loans.use: The purchase of a plot of land

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: Personal expenses.

loans.name: Marisela

texts.es: Marisela, de 20 años, es una joven muy trabajadora, vive en casa de sus padres, junto a sus 3 hermanos mayores. Como es la hija mayor, se siente en la responsabilidad de apoyar a sus padres. Es de esta manera que durante el día trabaja en local que ofrece servicio de Internet, y al término del día se dedica  a la venta de cosméticos. Lo modalidad de venta de este último trabajo es por medio de  catálogos a sus amigas y vecinas de su barrio, quienes le pagan semanalmente, eso le motiva a continuar con este negocio. Esta muy satisfecha por la labor que desempeña; ya que mediante estos ingresos apoya a sus hermanos menores, y eso le da mucha satisfacción personal. En  adelante planea ampliar su negocio y con esas ganancias quiere forjarse una carrera técnica. Es su primer crédito con MFP, y se compromete pagar sus cuotas oportunamente, además está agradecida con todas las personas que hicieron posible en integrarse al crédito grupal. Con el crédito que solicita, tiene planeado comprar más productos de belleza, de esa manera piensa abastecer con la demanda de sus clientes.
texts.en:
Marisela, 20, is a hard-working young woman who lives with her parents and 3 older brothers. Because she is the oldest daughter, she feels a duty to take care of her parents. During the day, she sells Internet services and during the evening, cosmetics. She sells cosmetics from a catalog to her friends and neighbors and they pay her weekly. The revenue from the business is her motivation for continuing it. She is very happy with the business because the income allows her to support her younger siblings, something of great personal satisfaction for her. In the future, she plans to expand her business and use the earnings from it to forge a career in technology. This is Marisela's first MFP loan and she is committed to repaying it on time. She says, too, that she is very grateful to everyone who made it possible for her to join the lending group. She will use the loan to buy more beauty products so that she can meet the demand for them.

Translated from Spanish by Jere Wiseman, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buy beauty products to resell.

loans.name: Bendiya 3 Group

texts.fr:
Les dix membres du groupe BENDIYA 3 sont des femmes mariées  avec une moyenne d’âge de 35ans, en moyenne 3  enfants et  qui  vivent dans des  familles polygames à MOSSIBOUGOU un des villages de la commune de LOULOUNI dans la sous préfecture  de LOULOUNI, 3ème région administrative du Mali. 
Elles collaborent avec l’institution de microfinance Soro Yiriwaso afin de mener à bien leurs activités agricoles pendant l’hivernage. Elles sont à leur deuxième prêt avec l’institution, le prêt passé a été bien remboursé.
Les spéculations cultivées  sont :, l’arachide, le riz et le pois sucré avec  MAMA C., la présidente du groupe.
Avec son prêt, elle compte acheter des intrants et les petits matériels pour entretenir : 2 ,5 hectares. 
La production est vendue à une clientèle composée d’hommes et de femmes au niveau du village, au marché de du village de DALLEN et au marché de LOULOUNI après la récolte. 
Elle compte réaliser un bénéfice moyen de 95.500 FCFA par campagne, qui servira à payer son prêt et  aider son mari à subvenir à certains besoins de la famille.
texts.en:
The ten members of the group BENDIYA 3 are married women with an average age of 35. They each have 3 children on average and live in polygamous families in Moosibougou, one of the villages in the commune of Loulouni in the Sikasso Region of southern Mali. They collaborate with the Microfinance insitution Soro Yiriwaso in order to successfully carry out their agricultural activities during winter. This is their second loan with the institution, with the first being duly repaid. The crops in which they invest are: peanuts, rice and pois sucre nuts. Mama C. is the president of the group. WIth her loan, she intends to buy agricultural products and equipment to cultivate 2.5 hectares. After the harvest, the produce is sold to a mixed male and female clientele in the village and at the markets in Dallen and Loulouni. She hopes to make an average profit of 95 500 FCFA each season, which will enable her to repay her loan and to help her husband provide for the needs of the family.

Translated from French by Kate Bennett, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Achat d’intrants et petits matériels agricoles.

loans.name: Bendiya 4 Group

texts.fr:
Le groupe BENDIYA 4 est constitué de sept femmes mariées  ayant une moyenne d’âge de 36 ans,  4  enfants et vivant  dans des  familles polygames à MOSSIBOUGOU un des villages de la commune de LOULOUNI dans la sous préfecture  de LOULOUNI, 3ème région administrative du Mali. 
Elles collaborent avec l’institution de microfinance Soro Yiriwaso afin de mener à bien leurs activités agricoles pendant l’hivernage. Elles sont à leur deuxième prêt avec l’institution, le prêt passé a été bien  remboursé.
La spéculation  principale cultivée est le pois sucré.  
MACHITAN C., la présidente du groupe, compte acheter, avec son prêt, des intrants, les petits matériels et le désherbage de 1hectare. 
La production est vendue après la récolte à une clientèle composée d’hommes et de femmes au niveau du village, au marché du village de DALLEN et au marché de LOULOUNI. 
Elle compte réaliser un bénéfice moyen de 45 000FCFA par campagne. Son bénéfice lui permettra de payer son prêt et à préparer le trousseau  mariage de sa fille.
Elle souhaite entretenir  cette collaboration avec Soro Yiriwaso afin d’ exploiter un espace cultural encore plus grand pour mieux en tirer plus de gains.
texts.en:
The group BENDIYA 4 is made up of 7 married women with an average age of 34. They each have 4 children on average and live in polygamous families in Moosibougou, one of the villages in the commune of Loulouni in the Sikasso Region of southern Mali. They collaborate with the Microfinance insitution Soro Yiriwaso in order to successfully carry out their agricultural activities during winter. This is their second loan with the institution, with the first being duly repaid. Their principal activity is cultivating pois sucre nuts. MACHITAN C., the president of the group, intends to use her loan to pay for agricultural products, tools and weeding for 1 hectare. The produce is sold after the harvest to male and female clientele in the village, and at the markets in Dallen and Loulouni. She hopes to generate an average profit of 45 000FCFA each season. This profit will enable her to repay her loan and to prepare her daughter's wedding dress. She hopes to maintain this collaboration with Soro Yiriwaso in order to cultivate a larger plot of land and make even bigger profits.

Translated from French by Kate Bennett, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Achat d’intrants, petits matériels agricoles et frais de main d’œuvre.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: Personal expenses.

loans.name: Isatu

texts.en:
Isatu K. is married to a trader and has three children. She sells traditional gara tie-dyed clothing and has ten years of experience. Her business was initially financed by her husband and began as a food-items shop but has since changed to gara tie-dyed clothing. Isatu is very hardworking and jovial.

Isatu has a good loan repayment history. She needs a loan of 3,000,000 SLL in order to add to her stock. She hopes to use the proceeds to educate her children to university level and to construct a house.

loans.use: To buy more cloth  to sell

loans.name: Bendiya  5 Group

texts.fr:
BENDIYA 5 est un regroupement de 10 femmes mariées  ayant une moyenne d’âge de 33 ans, 3  enfants et vivent  dans des  familles polygames à MOSSIBOUGOU un des villages de la commune de LOULOUNI dans la sous-préfecture  de LOULOUNI, 3ème région administrative du Mali. 
Elles collaborent avec l’institution de microfinance Soro Yiriwaso afin de mener à bien leurs activités agricoles pendant l’hivernage. 
Elles sont à leur septième prêt avec l’institution, les cinq prêts passés se sont  bien dénoués.
La spéculation majoritairement cultivée est : le pois sucré à  l’image de MARATOU O..
Avec son prêt, elle compte acheter des intrants, les petits matériels et  recruter de la main d'œuvre   pour  exploiter  1,5 hectare. 
La production est vendue après la récolte, au marché de du village de DALLEN et au marché de LOULOUNI à une clientèle composée d’hommes et de femmes. 
Elle compte réaliser un bénéfice moyen de 75 000 FCFA par campagne.
Son bénéfice lui permettra de payer son prêt et aider son mari dans certaines dépenses de la famille.
Elle souhaite entretenir  cette collaboration avec Soro Yiriwaso afin d’ exploiter un espace cultural encore plus grand pour mieux en tirer plus de gains.
texts.en:
BENDIYA 5 is a group of 10 married with an average age of 33. They each have 3 children on average and live in polygamous families in Mossibougou, one of the villages in the commune of Loulouni in the Sikasso Region of southern Mali. They collaborate with the Microfinance insitution Soro Yiriwaso in order to successfully carry out their agricultural activities during winter. This is their seventh loan with the institution, with the past five being duly repaid. The main crop they cultivate is the pois sucre nut. This is the crop cultivated by Maratou O.. With her loan, Maratou O. intends to purchase the agricultural products, tools and labour requried to cultivate 1,5 hectares. The produce is sold after the harvest at the markets in Dallen and Louloni to a mixed clientele of men and women. She hopes to make an average profit of 75 000 FCFA each season. This profit will enable her to repay her loan and to help her husband with various household expenses. She hopes to maintain this collaboration with Soro Yiriwaso in order to cultivate and even bigger plot of land and make bigger profits.

Translated from French by Kate Bennett, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Frais de labour, semences, engrais, herbicides, sarclage et petits matériels agricoles.

loans.name: Flor De Aleli Group

texts.es:
Este grupo solidario se llama Flor de Alelí. Esta ubicado en la comunidad de Hueyapan, Tétela del Volcán, en el estado de Morelos, México. El grupo esta conformado por 5 integrantes que se conocen y son vecinos. Este es su primer préstamo con Fundacion Realidad.
La integrante del grupo la señora Aurelia Pérez A. tiene 56 años de edad, estudio la primaria ya de grande obteniendo su certificado de primaria. Tiene 2 hijos 1 hombre y 1 mujer, Orlando Rivera tiene 30 años de edad y Maria Isabel tiene 22 años de edad. La Señora Aurelia tiene su tienda de abarrotes y vende frutas, aguacates y nuez por mayoreo y solicito su préstamo para comprar mercancía aceite, jabón, papel higiénico, sal, azúcar, huevo, refrescos, chile pasilla, chile huajillo y dulces para surtir su tienda de abarrotes inicio su negocio hace 15 años por necesidad y para sobrevivir, ya que se quedo viuda y su esposo le heredo terrenos con árboles de aguacates, su hijo le ayuda en las labores del campo, abona los árboles de aguacate, la milpa, ella acude al mercado de Yecaplixtla los martes y los viernes a vender sus aguacates y nueces por mayoreo por tonelada, también en Ozumba vende sus productos.  Su hija le ayuda en las labores de la casa y atender la tienda de abarrotes cuando ella no esta por que sale a vender sus frutas, su negocio esta en Hueyapan en Barrio san Bartolo en su casa la tienda de abarrotes llamada Lucero de la mañana y en el campo sus terrenos de árboles de aguacate. Ella tiene una camioneta en la que utiliza para trasportar su fruta y verdura pero esta descompuesta le faltan las llantas y le quiere comprar las llantas para utilizarla en el negocio ya que tiene que rentar una camioneta para ir a vender sus aguacates y nueces. A ella le gusta ir a vender sus frutas el aguacate y las nueces a Ozumba  porque obtiene más ganancias y en la tienda de abarrotes no se ven las ganancias. Su negocio le a ayudado mucho a sacar adelante a sus hijos pues es sola se quedo viuda y pudo sacarlos adelante sola. Las ganancias de la tienda las utiliza en la alimentación y gastos de la casa y las ganancias de venta de las nueces y aguacates las utiliza en seguir invirtiendo, compra árboles de nuez las corta y las empaca, compra abono para la milpa y par los arboles de aguacate, utiliza tractor para barbechar. Sus sueños y esperanza son llegar a la vejez, tener vida y salud para seguir trabajando y que sus hijos estén bien y no se enfermen. Ella esta muy contenta con el préstamo por que va a comprar más cosas para aumentar su negocio.
En barrio san Bartolo en Hueyapan hay muchos árboles, pinos, F., arboles frutales peras, duraznos, tejocotes, manzana, membrillo. Chile manzano, pimiento. El clima es frió. 
Los integrantes del grupo son Marcela Ramírez F. y va a utilizar su préstamo para comprar jitomates, tomates, lechuga, cilantro, cebolla, etc. para comenzar su negocio de ventas de frutas y legumbres, la señora Dominga Sandoval F. va a comprar materia prima platos desechables, verduras, carnes tortillas, condimentos, arroz para elaborar su comida de antojitos Mexicanos, la señora Maria Isabel B. B. va a comprar ropa para dama blusas, pantalones, ropa interior para niño y niñas, calcetas, la señora Francisca B. C. va a comprar fertilizante químico y orgánico para abonar su producción de  durazno, la señora Aurelia Pérez A. va a comprar mercancía para surtir su tienda (reinicio) y surtirse de fruta por mayoreo para vender. 
Las integrantes del grupo quiere decir a Kiva y a Fundacion Realidad “Les agradecemos mucho porque confían en nosotros y vamos a cumplir para que nos sigan prestando, gracias por que no nos conocen y nos apoyan con su préstamo”
texts.en:
This group is called Flor de Aleli. It's located in Hueyapan in the Mexican state of Morelos. The group has 5 members, all neighbors who have long known one another. This is the group's first Fundacion Realidad loan. Sra. Aurelia P. A., a member of the group, is 56 years old. She has 2 children: a son, Orlando, 30, and a daughter, Maria Isabel, 22. Sra. Aurelia owns a grocery store and sells wholesale supplies of fruits, avocados and nuts. She is applying for a loan to buy cooking oil, soap, toilet paper, salt, sugar, eggs, cold drinks, different kinds of chiles and sweets that she will resell in her store. She started the business 15 years ago because she needed the income from it to live after her husband died. He left her a small farm planted with avocado trees. Her son helped her with the farm work, fertilizing the fields. She goes to the Yecaplixtla market on Tuesdays and Fridays to sell bulk supplies of avocadoes and nuts. She sells in Ozumba, as well. Sra. Aurelia's daughter helps her with the housework and tends the store when she is away. The business is in her house in the San Bartolo neighborhood of Hueyapan. The store is called Lucero. Sra. Aurelia has a truck in which she carries her goods to market, but it's in poor condition and needs new tires. She has had to rent a truck recently which has been a drain on her income. She would like to sell her goods in Ozumba because she can make more money there at a time when the store is barely getting by. The earnings from the store go to paying the family's everyday expenses. Earnings from the wholesale business are reinvested: buying nut trees; harvesting the nuts; packing them; buying fertilizer for the fields and the avocado trees; and using a tractor to prepare the land for new plantings. Sra. Aurelia's hopes for the future are to reach a ripe old age, in good health and still able to work, and that her children be well and happy. She is pleased to get the loan and she will use it to buy more things for her business. There are many kinds of trees in San Bartolo--pines, flowered trees, pear, peach, tejocotes, apple, etc. The climate is cold. The members of the group are Sra. Marcela R. F., who will buy fruits and vegetables to resell; Sra. Dominga Sandoval F. who will supplies to make Mexican antojitos for her prepared food business; Sra. Maria Isabel B. B. who will buy women's clothing to resell; Sra. Francisca B. Cortes who will buy chemical and organic fertilizers for her farming business; and Sra. Aurelia P. A. who will buy stock for her grocery business and supplies for her wholesale fruit and nut business. To Kiva and Fundacion Realidad, the members say "We are very grateful that you have trusted us and we will fulfill the terms of the loan so that you will continue to loan to us. We thank you because you don't know us and you support us anyway".

Translated from Spanish by Jere Wiseman, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Working capital for multiple businesses.

loans.name: God’S Blessing #2. Group

texts.en:
Bendu W., who is holding the sign, is the leader of this group of five borrowers called God’s Blessing #2.

Bendu is 35 years old, single and has five children who range from 5 to 14 years old. She was not privileged to attend school due to poverty. She cares for one sibling. 

For three years, she has been selling beans and wheat in the Redlight Market on the outskirts of Monrovia, Liberia.

She plans to use her 6,000-Liberian-Dollar portion of this 30,000-Liberian-Dollar group loan to buy more bags of beans and wheat.
